title: American Assets Trust
pros: Great work/life balance, amenities, staff and leadership.
cons: None to report at this time.

title: Low-Quality Employer, Toxic Work Culture
pros: This was the worst employer I've ever worked for and I wish I had paid attention to all the negative reviews. The hiring manager told me during the interview that it was a great place to work. The reality is that American Assets management is unethical and encourages unhealthy competition between employees. There's no work/life balance and you're expected to work weekends. Burnout is common and management doesn't care about employees' well-being at all. The only thing they value is money. This is why American Assets is constantly getting sued (more than seven lawsuits in San Diego alone in the past year). There was high turnover at the property I worked at. People either quit in a short amount of time because of the toxic work culture or were fired. Don't expect job security or loyalty from American Assets.
cons: Management doesn't comply with some laws and encourages an unhealthy work culture.

title: Varied leadership
pros: Work life balance depends on department. Nice office.
cons: Management/leadership depends on the department. Tone at the top doesn’t always trickle down to middle management. 5 days in office is archaic.

title: American Assets Devalues Employees
pros: Pay is good for some positions.
cons: American Assets has to pay good wages, otherwise who would work for them? The company has a rigid, toxic work culture. Poor work-life balance, micromanaging and a lack of communication from supervisors are the norm. Management lacks empathy and respect for employees. They claim that they want to provide a fair and inclusive workplace, yet they stifle employees and ignore their complaints. And they're obsessed with appearances. My former supervisor is unprofessional and lacks leadership skills. I had a warning sign that he was a bad boss when he asked me an inappropriate question during the interview. His boss isn't any better. I wasn't the only one who was miserable. My co-workers would say things like, "If I'm one minute late from break, I'll be in trouble" and "I hate the office politics here." If you value your mental health, don't work for American Assets.

title: Amazing work atmosphere and support!
pros: Easy access to support, training programs and materials. Great team environment and beautiful properties. Excellent benefits and fair salaries. HR works hard to accommodate everyone and make sure they feel welcomed. Corporate employees are very friendly and helpful. Work for Earnest Rady!
cons: I wouldn't say its a downside but there's room for improvement. Some procedures are not efficient and things could be more consistent/uniformed. Contracts process is very time consuming and tedious. High insurance requirements make it difficult for vendors to offer us good rates for services or even work for us.

title: Do not recommend
pros: On site staff are wonderful people
cons: Company itself is not what it should be

title: Great company
pros: This is a great company to work for.
cons: I did not see any cons working for this company

pros: Majority nice people and coworkers. Great portfolio, care about their assets. Good stepstone til you find a batter opportunity.
cons: No growth, some managers have questionable intentions, managers do not mentor, I've seen temper tantrums from a superior, some micro managing and be-mottling but certain managers, there are a lot of "politics", arrogance of certain management, no recognition for busting your bum, low moral and motivation, far below average pay, little to no yearly raise and poor bonuses.

title: Great people & comfortable lifestyle
pros: I'm a recent new hire at AAT, and thus far everyone has been kind and welcoming. The team is high performing, but with good work/life balance (including yoga twice each week from noon - 1pm). The facilities are beautiful, and the assets owned by AAT are irreplaceable. I'm very happy with my new position and would recommend AAT to any prospective employees!
cons: Executives generally want you to be in-office (i.e. minimal work from home). There are opportunities to get things done on your own time at home, but generally speaking you're expected to be on-site during work hours. That being said - this is in many ways a pro, as the work stops when you leave the office which is not the case with many companies. I have found this to be highly beneficial for my life, both physically and emotionally.

title: So much potential but toxic culture is holding them back
pros: Advancement within company is pretty good and they have amazing assets. Onsite living an option for managers.
cons: Company culture is toxic. Profit driven instead of value driven, at least in the multi family side. Business systems are chaotic as they use multiple platforms and there are always integration issues which makes managing an asset 10x harder than it should be. Pay is awful, HR department is shady and gaslight hard workers. Cliques are a huge part of the culture and not in a good way. Offers no proper training what so ever. This company has so much potential but a lot of bad actors in mid level management are holding the company back.

title: If you can find something else, just go!
pros: Majority of the staff are truly genuine and cares, take note I said “staff.” Anyone in an office, consider “stuck up, obnoxious, and rude.” Truly micro-managers, they get hard-ons by bullying their staff. All the good managers were either real human beings and were just too nice and smart to stick around and left, and now we’re stuck with the bad ones. Total culture shock at this place with managers having a huge language barrier; please have management attend ESL classes. Management loves to humiliate staff whenever mistakes occur and provides little to no training what so ever.
cons: High, as in very HIGH turn-over rate. Managers don't care about their staff and loves it when their staff fails and makes mistakes, it gives managers something to talk about in their management meetings.

title: Employee Beware
pros: Beautiful building, security, delicious cafe downstairs. and free parking.
cons: First and foremost, this company does not train, they expect you to know it all on the job and if you ask questions twice, you are labeled incompetent. Your performance on the job is all criticized at the time of your review, there is NO verbal warnings. Most managers have been there for many years and they supervise unfairly, they have their favorites and let them get away with rules, while others that are in their radar, punished constantly. They do not foster a healthy, encourage for success environment. And be careful, HR is not a safe haven, unfair treatment and assumptions are quickly determined. So if you want to work in the "lion's den" then apply and get hired. Good luck!

title: AWFUL
pros: Not a lot of nice things to say about this company. Nice picnic I guess. The owner is a good man who just has bad people under him.
cons: Awful HR. While I was there a a VP was indicted. For 6 months I listened to my manager lie, gossip and discriminate against co-workers and customers. She was away from the office 30% of the week with no explanation. Did not follow company policies 50% of the time. Also a girl transferred over from another office because her boss had been verbally abusing her and forcing her to take on the manager's duties while the manager was absent. HR would never respond to emails. Huge violation. My last day she lied about losing her keys and asked for mine then had HR call me after I left and tell me not to come back with no explanation. Terrible place.

title: Rady isn't as great as you think.
pros: Multiple locations throughout the city
cons: -Extremely disorganized within each site all the way up to corporate office. What I mean is that you have a procedure to follow and you follow it, corporate adds more steps. So then you follow it the next time, and then you're asked "Why did you do it that way" and you run in circles and the corporate office continues to move the goal posts. -Extremely low pay for the position

title: Happy New Hire!
pros: Great working environment. Awesome medical benefits including 401(k) plan. 17 PTO days the first year of employment! That doesn't even include the 3 sick days! Free life insurance for you and your family! Onsite gym and a discount to the in-house cafeteria. Excellent work-life balance.
cons: None. Ok, well with the great food at the in-house café, I may gain some weight. But then that'll come off going to the onsite free gym. Best of both worlds! :)

title: Egg Shells
pros: Great Company Portfolio, Great Benefits, Intelligent Co-workers, Great Experience in Corporate Setting
cons: Uncomfortable working environment, management taking credit for your work, very unappreciative, raises are rare, only Execs get raises, low self-esteem and cocky upper-management

title: Women In Leadership
pros: The VP of the company is a woman and she is a wealth of knowledge, strong sense of teamwork and that the company is a family.
cons: Managers have a tendency to micromanage and high turnover rate.

title: Small company, great pay
pros: Pay was insane Benefits were insane Co-workers Lots of money in the company so if you ever needed anything it was usually a yes Company events
cons: Favoritism can happen at times

pros: Promote from within. Multi cultural
cons: Company but operates like a mom and pop shop

title: Great Compaany
pros: Company has a bright future n multi family housing. Lots of great employees. Great bonuses and incentives.
cons: Decision made by CFO without considering the impact on lower level employees

title: Beautiful location
pros: Attractive real estate portfolio and corporate location
cons: Disconnected management and leadership, lack of communication

title: Great company to work for!
pros:
competitive pay
easy going work culture
diverse
cons: everyone one loves their job so not enough growth opportunities

title: Nice place to work
pros: Nice office and friendly people
cons: Lack of communication from management

title: Community Manager
pros: None that I can think of
cons: A horrible company to work for doesn't care about staff or people. Wants to capitalize money for shareholders at any costs and will run nice assets into the ground.

title: Leasing Consultant
pros: Great healthcare benefits, hr staff is friendly.
cons: ultant

title: 90 days pay
pros: Get 90 days of pay
cons: Company Sends temps through staffing agency to avoid hiring full-time.

title: Toxic culture
pros: The property is very attractive.
cons: Would 10/10 not recommend. Management is extremely toxic.

title: Good
pros: Good company and and culture
cons: Bad work overtime exhausting stress

title: Good
pros: Everything is very good woo
cons: Nothing is bad for them

title: Good Company and Opportunities
pros: Hybrid, PTO, good health insurance. Everyone is really friendly and managers are helpful when needed. Recognizes hard work and offer promotions when available.
cons: Training could be improved, but still good.

title: Arbor
pros: Worked in smaller office and most coworkers were friendly
cons: No training, expect you to know their processes and if you ask questions they make you feel stupid

title: Good Underwriting Job
pros: Salary position. Access to learn SFR and Multifamily financing. Managers don’t breathe down your backs. Good position if you enjoy looking at screen and staying at desk all day.
cons: Intense workload during busy seasons. Salary does not compensate you for overtime. Pay and bonus increases are negligible compared to increased workload for lower end promotions. Pay and bonuses are negotiated during slow times so that the company has negotiating power to say they are not busy to pay you more. Real estate is cyclical, so the timing of pay discussions always coincides with the slowest time for loans. You are expected to bend over backward when asked. Bonuses are not guaranteed. Lay offs tend to happen around bonus season. Despite title changes during promotions, you are still doing the same work

title: It’s okay
pros: Pay, the people and traveling
cons: Too much work not enough staff

title: Overall solid
pros: Good pay and work life balance
cons: Benefits are not the best

title: Entry level
pros: Good culture and people here
cons: In person 5 days a week

title: Great opportunities for driven employees
pros: Arbor has progressed me into new roles with more complex situations for the past couple years. I believe my exposure and training is leading me down a path of success and my work has been appreciated by my team/superiors. Learning as situations arise, I have a mentor on my team to bounce questions to and it has help me become a better employee. I hope to maintain my success as i work my way into bigger roles at Arbor.
cons: Arbor gives its employees a lot of trust and responsibility. Some employees see this as a great opportunity to accel, others may be intimidated if they prefer a constant collaborative setting. This could be a con for someone fresh out of college who is entering their first job.

title: Great Company to Join
pros: Work life balance: bank holidays off and plenty of starting PTO. Hybrid work environment. Benefits: good benefits, relatively affordable insurance Competent and accessible management: management have a good grasp of daily operations and are easy to bring questions and concerns to People: everyone is kind and happy to work with one another. Plenty of events and small tokens of appreciation Facilities: offices are modern and clean
cons: Upper management does seem to want to push for more time in office. However no such call has happened yet.

title: Arbor Experience
pros: From the beginning, I knew Arbor was the right long-term company for me. The people, management, and industry has made my time enjoyable. After spending 11 years at a regional bank, I was nervous about transitioning to a new role at a different company, but Arbor made that process easy from the beginning. The work-life balance is excellent, and management organizes great events like holiday and summer parties, as well as casual gatherings. Overall, I am very happy with my experience at Arbor.
cons: There are no major drawbacks to Arbor, but one minor improvement could be introducing new employees to their department in person. For example, when a new Asset Manager joins, it would be helpful if someone took them around to meet the other Asset Managers in the department.

title: A rough place
pros: Excellent learning experience to understand underwriting bridge and perm debt, CLOs, and servicing
cons: Very rough work environment with no training or mentoring

title: Great Job and Opportunity
pros: Work environment is amazing and coworkers are very easy to get along with and talk to. Hard work pays off truly at this job. I came here with hardly any experience, I listened, I asked questions, and kept a positive mentality even on the hardest days. I got an unexpected promotion after only 5 months. Pretty amazing!
cons: Not too many cons on my side. Sometimes it takes a little bit for an issue to be resolved, but nothing negative. Just move on and come back to it!

title: Happy I Left
pros: Good time off policy, good holidays.
cons: Raises are very small. The biggest problem is that senior management doesn't care about the people who do the work. They constantly change procedures without stopping to consider the people who actually do the jobs. Work-life balance is given lip service. There are not enough people to do the work but they are told overtime is available. When people can't work OT, they are told it must mean no additional staff is need. This leads to burnout ans so many people have left.

title: Arbor Journey/Experience
pros: It has been a pleasure getting to know the business and the people at Arbor over my tenure, I have been delighted to be a part of such a special group, and proud to say I work here, where the culture and atmosphere are second to none.
cons: There is always room for more training & development, this area has definitely improved since I started at Arbor, but there is still more to improve on.

title: Great people, who are always willing to help!
pros: The company culture is a big draw to Arbor. I am new in my role, and my team is always willing to help me learn something new. We all have a "same team, same goal" mentality which makes the work that much more enjoyable.
cons: It is a great privilege that Arbor is very pro-hybrid work. The difficulty is that for new employees, in a relatively empty office, it feels pretty isolating, and you rely on virtual means to ask your team questions, it delays the process, etc. It's a great time when people are in the office and everyone's talking and collaborating; so I wish I could experience that more.

title: Best opportunities for growth and promotions. Work/Life balance is number 1 here!
pros: Excellent benefits and wages with PTO. Happy to work without micro-management, This company is moving in an advanced direction of automation to allow for its' consistent growth in the market. Excellent training and resources for further advancement opportunities.
cons: There is not one con. Hard work and dedication is recognized and rewarded.

title: Green Flag company that cares about their employees
pros: Mangement cares about things like employee safety (if the weather is bad WFH is an option) The Healthcare offers pricing based on the tier of your salary (this is something more places should do and really impressed me). The people/department I work with are and extremely dedicated and talented bunch of people. Everyone cares about the job they do.
cons: The list is short. I would like to see more outside of the box thinking and solutioning. But that is a culture thing and just a preference of mine, not really a con.

title: Job is fine but pay seems unreasonably low
pros: Fun group of analysts to work with
cons: Pay seems to be much lower than some other comparable firms

title: Arbor employment
pros: Working at Arbor always has a supportive work environment, opportunities for professional growth, and competitive benefits. Employees appreciate the company's commitment to sustainability and innovation, which fosters a sense of pride and purpose.
cons: I cannot think of anything that is a con I enjoy my job and the confidence that the company has with all of their employees. Arbor is considered a desirable place to work due to its positive work environment and the confidence the company has in all of its employees.

title: Treasury Accounting Specialist II
pros: Good work life balance, interested in employee development, positive workplace culture, promotes employee health & welfare.
cons: Training needs to improve and be more continuous to ensure quality of work, technology could improve in several areas.

title: Overall good experience
pros: Smallish feel Good benefits and community involvement You get what you give Hybrid/remote work opportunities
cons: Growth opportunities can stall out Upper level management doesn't change easily Training could use some improvement Heavy and at times unmanageable workload

title: Abor Realty Trust Review
pros: Arbor is a really comfortable place to work. The company cares about their employees and their outside life as well. managers ensure that training is priority to ensure you have the best shot at succeeding in the current role you hold. I feel compensation is very fair for the amount of work we complete on a daily basis.
cons: There isn't many cons but if I had to choose one it would be lack of community involvement. I would love to see Arbor get involved in more than just environmental needs.

title: Great Company to work for!
pros: The amount of support you get from your co-workers and upper management is what makes coming to work easy. Work life balance is also great at Arbor. Recognized for your hard work.
cons: The office location is a little far from where I live but other than that, I have no complaints about Arbor.

title: I Love My Job
pros: Arbor is a great place to work. I have recommended a few people and most are still with Arbor. If you put your best foot forward, you will not go unnoticed. Family is very important to me and Arbor works with you to ensure you have a great work/life balance.
cons: Better communication between Asset Management and Operations.

title: Content Employee
pros: -Managers back the work of their team -Great benefits (time off, holidays, work life balance) -Work as an individual contributor, so you are in control of your success -Enjoyable culture in the office -Hybrid schedule -Ability to travel based on the position -Interesting work
cons: -Location of the office (Buffalo)

title: Great Place to Build a Career
pros: Arbor does a really good job rewarding hard work and providing opportunities for career growth and advancement. Management is flexible and understands the importance of work/life balance to ensure their employees are happy and has a culture that promotes building positive relationships with team members. I love the people I work with and enjoy the challenges that come with each day being a little bit different so it always remains interesting!
cons: With a higher interest rate environment we have encountered increased pressure from Investors to monitor property condition, but Arbor as a whole has done a great job continuing to perform well despite the challenges we have been given. Our leadership gives me confidence that we can survive any economic cycle.

title: Nice place to work
pros: Location, salary and most people
cons: Marketing team wasn’t pleasant to work with and took credit for things they didn’t accomplish.

title: Good first CRE job
pros: Great team environment, steep learning curve.
cons: No real structured training program.

title: Fairly decent place to work
pros: Manager is very knowledgeable and supportive. He doesn’t get mad if an error is made. He will tackle issues head-on and help to resolve issues without making you feel bad about the error. Flexible - once the work is done. Does not micromanage and leaves you to take ownership of your deals but is there if you need help. Great summer and holiday events for employees
cons: Pay not competitive Gossip culture Clique culture Nothing is confidential - ur business will be talked about. Promotions scarce

title: Review
pros: Great place to begin your career.
cons: None to speak of during my brief stay.

title: Strong Company with a Great Culture
pros: Having worked here for 11 plus years I have seen the company grow both in size but also in the culture. Arbor is a great place to work. It has the benefits of a large publicly traded company but has a smaller, employee friendly environment. Senior Management has guided the company through multiple economic cycles, and the experienced and long tenured employee base has always kept the company performing strong financially. Growth is always available to those that put in the effort and earn it. I plan to be with Arbor for a very long time.
cons: Salary and Benefits are on par with the industry but are constantly being evaluated to make sure that the company can attract and retain talent.

pros: culture within the work place
cons: pay, communication from the top

title: Great company to work for
pros: I love my manager and their managing style. It has helped me improve my own, along with helping me increase in title and grow within the company. Benefits are great myself, my wife, and child don’t pay a dime for most doctor related things.
cons: I think experiences may vary depending upon management styles within the different groups/departments. There are great leaders in most departments, but there are some gaps between them and the not as great ones.

pros: career advancement and promotion from within
cons: long hours, minimal work life balance

title: Good place to work
pros: Great place to learn and develop in the commercial real estate world
cons: Office location is a pain and the company is a little over the top on being in the office vs working from home

title: Great Learning Experience and Company Culture
pros: -Hybrid work schedule conducive to a family schedule -Upper Management expertise -Collaborative Teams -New Office Facilities w/ Gym and a lot of good lunch spots in the surrounding area
cons: Learning curve can be steep and Lenders change guidelines regularly, but the company does a great job of trying to stay ahead of the curve and adapting to ever changing rules.

title: Great Company
pros:
Rewards and recognizes hard work. 
Healthy culture that promotes from within.
cons: Inconsistency on who gets promoted and when.

title: Come join us
pros: Open communication, supportive leadership/management, respectful, good work-life balance, flexible work schedule,
cons: Continue to promote within and increase staff to accommodate our steadily increasing loan growth

title: Great Culture
pros: Great hours, convenient location, easy work loads.
cons: Light work load, analyst errors

title: For your sanity, look elsewhere.
pros: Health insurance was decent and not over priced.
cons: 1. Their processes are archaic and they can't seem to leverage technology to streamline or reduce manual efforts, either because they won't spend the money on it or because they do not hire the proper talent. Instead, they expect the employee to offset the lack of technology with grueling and redundent efforts all while increasing the volume of work with each quarter. 2. Some departments are woefully understaffed and remain that way, not because of the covid workforce throttles, but because they won't hire more people because they are "working on automation and technology". The expectation to offset the staffing issues is transferred to the employee where the demands often meant working well beyond an 8 hour shift and often on weekends and holidays. 3. The company is split into silos, no one works together with a common goal. And the different "sides" of the building are often pit against one another where accountability is non-existent, it's always someone else's fault. 4. Their remote work policy and hybrid work environment is a joke and it is weaponized to ensure compliance or it will be taken away. 5. There is no growth opportunity, every team has a handful of employees and if you're trying to get into the management level you have to wait until someone gets fired or quits.

title: Toxic Workplace
pros: No benefits to working here.
cons: Management is unrealistic and harsh.

title: Insurance Department-Arbor Realty Trust
pros: Flexible, hybrid company with lots of opportunity for growth. A great place to expand knowledge on the commercial insurance field. Receptive of hard work and new ideas. There are people in the company that have started as receptionists that have been able to launch a full career in commercial real estate. Upper management is extremely approachable. Professional company without feeling too “corporate”.
cons: Not a con, but must be open minded when it comes to change. The commercial real estate market & insurance markets are forever fluctuating, important to have strong change management skills and a change forward mindset.

title: Great Place to Work
pros: The People are great! Pay is good! Work Home balance is exceptional.
cons: Only goes up to 23 PTO days max

title: Great place to work!
pros: Coming from a large corporation to Arbor was an easy transition. Everyone is so helpful, knowledgeable and kind. The culture in the office is great and I currently work a hybrid schedule! It’s important to me to work for a company that treats their employees well & gives back to the community. Arbor does all of that and more. Could not recommend working here enough.
cons: I have nothing bad to say!

title: Great work environment
pros: Can learn from your coworkers and work on great transactions
cons: Nothing is wrong with the job

title: Good Company
pros: A lot of deal exposure for entry level roles. Great guys
cons: High turnover. Messy deals brought in by brokers. You’re expected to “work with what you have” a lot of times which is not the standard at other shops

title: 1-year analyst review
pros: high volume workplace, lots of personal growth,
cons: poor upper management and company processes. Minimal training

title: Great Work Life Balance
pros: Great work life balance. Hybrid Work Schedule. Daytime hours with weekends off. Great Training. Great PTO Package, with every Federal Holiday off including Black Friday. Early outs on Fridays from Memorial Day and Labor Day offered. Dress down Mondays and Fridays. Hour lunches. New Office has Game Room, and Bike Path. Employee appreciation by Human Resources provided. Monthly Birthday Recognition. Flexibility when needing to take time off for appointments. Career opportunities have really increased over the last few years, and recognition of performance has increased. Just a great work environment, people are friendly. Not a high school atmosphere. Team Members are willing to share information and training in order for you to succeed.
cons: Management varies from Department to Department. Some areas are more stringent than others. Not all management adopts company policies as readily as others. When suspicion of changes in economy are suspected management will micromanage, and reprimand talking on the floor with team members, even when work metrics are being met. Company is not open to local office fully remote positions in most departments. Promotional opportunities in some areas can take 2-3+ years, even when employees are going above and beyond, and are not always defined. Requests for additional assistance have occurred after an employee has left the company.

title: Happy to call Arbor home
pros: Arbor is the most positive work environment I’ve ever been apart of. I love my team and I really appreciate the culture of Arbor. I love the work/life balance and the people I interact with on a daily basis.
cons: No specific cons come to mind.

title: An amazing place to work
pros: Arbor has a lot to offer. A few perks are a game room, fitness room, paid holidays, casual Fridays, and some pretty amazing events sprinkled throughout the year. There is plenty of growth opportunities and they do promote from within the company. There is a good work/life balance.
cons: This is an office environment so there are cubicles. It is not really a con for me but can be an issue for some.

title: Fine
pros: Work/life balance is pretty good
cons: Doesn't pay well, hard to grow in

title: Awesome
pros: incredible atmosphere and culture. not one day has gone bye where I have dreaded going to work/the office

title: Very Clique

title: Arbor
pros: Great office culture. Learn a lot.

title: Great place to learn and grow a career
pros: Friendly, team-based environment with unlimited growth potential, good pay/benefits, job flexibility and invaluable experience.
cons: Overall, upper management has done a good job over the past couple years listening to employees on what can be done to make our experiences better and our lives easier. Could use some more complimentary company swag.

title: Refreshing and Challenging
pros:
Great work life balance 
Helpful coworkers
Positive energy
cons: I do not have any!

title: Good place to start your career
pros: Work life balance is great and decent pay.
cons: Everything has to be approved by upper management which prevents much work from being accomplished at a faster pace.

title: I truly enjoy this job!
pros: I enjoy how this job is structured. We receive monthly portfolios and can anticipate our workload in advance. The team is supportive and helpful for any questions that you may have. The environment is relaxed, there is never a time where it feels stressful or you feel micromanaged. I truly enjoy what I do and I feel a sense of belonging. It feels like the management is supportive and will help you move up in the company to advance your career. We have meetings each month to understand some of the operations of the other departments in Arbor. Work life balance is fantastic! Absolutely love the hybrid work schedule, it breaks up the week and it's nice having a balance of both.
cons: The only con that I have is the semi-monthly pay. That is the only thing that I wish could be changed.

title: Review
pros: Great company with a strong culture and good employees.
cons: Communication between upper management and staff is lacking at times

title: Not bad to start off in CRE
pros: Great guys in the office
cons: Poor training / steep learning curve

title: Run - run as fast as you can
pros: I can’t think of a single thing good thing to say about this place.
cons: Hands down the worst place I ever worked. Toxic & vengeful management.

title: Wonderful Company
pros: Positive atmosphere, Great Culture, Diverse staff, Great compensation, Career opportunities
cons: I can't think of anything

title: Great Company
pros: Great Company, Fast Paced. Fun.
cons: None to note that I can think of.

title: Burnt out, understaffed

cons: Overworked and understaffed. Constantly playing catch up. Thankless job, as clients and underwriters are never happy with you simply doing your job.

title: Good Place to Work
pros: Good Benefits and good atmosphere
cons: I don't have any downsides

title: Arbor Review
pros: Arbor has a great culture and very supportive senior management. There are several opportunities for growth as well.
cons: Lack of communication between departments sometimes.

title: Treasury Accounting
pros: Great place to work and grow. great team collaboration - management always available for questions and or support.
cons: Improve Training spectrum / Appoint trainers for each existing department.

title: Good company
pros: Great coworkers and supportive managers, lots of on the job training and collaboration
cons: Some processes are redundant but they’re working on improvements

title: Money is good till they burn you out
pros: Bonus paid out every February
cons: Will overwork, understaff and expect you to be thankful for every moment with the company.

title: Worst Company. Look Elsewhere
pros: Health insurance is okay but that’s about it. They have nothing else worth staying here for.
cons: -Terrible management. No growth opportunities. They expect you to do more work than you are paid for and you almost never get a raise. -All executives are out of touch. -You will truly not enjoy working here, especially when you receive no training. You can find so many better companies to work for. This place is awful.

title: Great Entry role
pros: Arbor screening is a great entry role to jump start real estate career. Great office culture. Good leadership. Good work life balance.
cons: Pay might be on lower end. What the job lacks in pay is made up in the value in the knowledge and experience gained.

title: Come Work with Us!
pros: 1) Wonderful team to work with day in and day out. 2) Management is great to work with. 3) Great work-life balance. 4) The company fosters a diverse and inclusive environment. 5) Hybrid office model (nice, big, and bright office) which fosters collaboration amongst teammates. 6) Everyone is very willing to help with questions.
cons: The training program could be improved to cover more aspects of the Portfolio Manager position. With that being said, it is difficult to train on every aspect of the job, and a lot of the learning is via on the job training.

cons: Training from binders. NO career advancement, many layers of mid management, toxic old-school work culture. You are an employee number. Morale is low, very easy to lose motivation. We were reminded every other week that we were lucky we were given the opportunity to work hybrid. Pizza party every couple of years.

title: Stay Away
pros: The pay is competitive Healthcare afford
cons: Just about everything minis above! I debating posting for several weeks. I strongly urge you to stay away from this company. Senior management needs to make drastic changes and become more realistic. Your job shouldn’t be more important than your family, health, or wellbeing. That’s what they expect. Work life balance doesn’t exist then. Potential to be a good company, but I don’t see the changes required to do so happening. Keep looking and take a pass here. Don’t settle nowhere is perfect but this isn’t the place you’ll wanna be.

title: Excellent Opportunity
pros: Excellent opportunity to gain exposure to the real estate lending industry.
cons: None to mention as of now

title: Great
pros: Learning Environment Friendly office Good management
cons: None at this point in time

title: Don't Expect to Advance to the Top
pros: Convenient location if you live in Nassau County. You will see business, since Arbor is known in the market. Arbor is in the business of making money so when the market is strong, deals do get done. If you are straight out of college, it's a decent place to hang for 18-24 months as you will get a decent amount of experience under your belt. If you are more seasoned --i.e., 10+ years of experience--then it's more a roll of the dice. Benefits are OK, but don't expect 2-for-1 401-k matching--or even 1-for-1. If you like bagels then you're all set: Free bagels on Wed morning.
cons: Small company mentality. Senior management does what it wants, doesn't deem it necessary to communicate with the rank and file. Keeps pay low and advancement is difficult unless you are a favored son/daughter. If your group head doesn't strongly push for recognition for his people don't expect to see raises or promotions coming your way. You will feel that while senior management gets richer, you are stuck in a rut. There's a large sense of people looking out for themselves. No true team spirit. Also, if you have ever worked in NYC you will note the big downside to being out of it by working in the 'burbs.

title: No work life balance
pros: Health insurance is good, time of decent.
cons: Training, no work life balance.

title: Good People, Poor Upper Management, Department to Department Issues
pros: The people you work with. Compensation
cons: Departments work only within themselves. If you try and work with other departments it becomes a nightmare of high school drama. Executive and senior management don't practice what they preach. Culture change is needed to stop this so employees can work in a healthy environment. This would benefit the company financial. Employees would be able to complete their work with no departmental drama. Team Work...you all work for the same company.

title: Should be your last choice
pros: Company was generally flexible about where and when you work as long as the work gets done. Except for benefits, the pay was market. The top benefit of working here is deal volume. You can see and learn a lot if you want to.
cons: The company is an old school boys club type environment, far more than other companies in the financial services/mortgage banking industry. There is very little diversity and employee satisfaction is not at all a concern. Deal related standards/best practices and employee well being are regularly thrown out in favor of profits, especially as quarters end. Again, this is somewhat true of many firms in the business, but it is unapologetically rampant here. The firm experienced multiple mass resignations while I was there. Benefits are severely under market, especially the 401k offering.

title: Arbor -- Not the Place for Professional Growth
pros: When the market was thriving, Arbor did see significant deal flow. In other words, Arbor was in the game. If you are fortunate to hook up with a manager who will support and promote you internally, you can go places.
cons: Most senior management is in it for themselves. Many of these managers may be good salespeople, etc. but they are lousy managers. Some simply don't care how their staff members are treated--unless it will somehow benefit them. Promotion/advancement can be very slow in coming and compensation is less than what you could get at a comparable firm.

title: Fantastic Place to Work
pros: Great company, I have perhaps one of the best team leads in the company, extremely knowledgeable, very capable, yet easy to talk to. The borrowers I work with are interesting, and there is a lot to learn with what you do day to day. Work is interesting, although can get repetitive, really, about my only gripe. Great benefits for a private company (no deductible health insurance is huge), vision, dental, etc. Good starting time off Hybrid office/WFH is great Overall, an excellent place to work.
cons: Dental insurance is expensive from what I've had previously, but health insurance is cheaper, tradeoff I guess. 401k match is weak, investment options are garbage, and fees are high. Need to be with Vanguard of Fidelity.

title: Okay for an entry level
pros: Travel, benefits, good entry level experience
cons: No upward growth unless you are unless you are apart of the "boys club". Too much favoritism and management doesn't stick up or go to bat for their staff. They're too worried about "rocking the boat" and their positions. You are pretty much left to learn on your own as everyone is spread too thin. Since the headquarter is not based in Buffalo there is limited opportunities. The office has too much gossip and drama like a High School. Unless you're apart of the club you're overlooked alot even those producers. Promises not followed through. Don't recognize great talent.

title: Fine Employer
pros: Met my salary requirements after negotiating.
cons: Bad communicators. Quick to lay people off. Got the job before the pandemic, assured me I was still okay to start during the pandemic, quit my other job, then barely a month later (after already pushing my start date back) they laid people off out of fear. Received no communication from my manager or other coworker (who was hired two weeks before me), and completely threw my career off track. Benefits are not great- half to wait months to be eligible and they are very unsympathetic to people's need for coverage during that time- I had to negotiate it in to my contract. 401k match is laughable.

title: Great Company w/ Poor Management
pros: Growing company with great opportunity to move into a portfolio manager position quickly if you are a strong analyst and detail oriented. I was able to earn multiple promotions within my first few years within the servicing department.
cons: Unfortunately due to the fast growing company over the past 10 years almost all of the VP's and managers have little to zero experience in leading people. It is a great company to start your career in commercial real estate servicing but I would not recommend staying there long-term.

title: I wouldn’t recommend working here
pros: Management doesn’t micromanage as long as your get your work done. Really nice offices. Decent pay. CU/DCUs are super nice and helpful with any and all questions.
cons: Deals are super sketchy. Sales guys run the company. Constant pushback when a deal shouldn’t work. You’re just a number. Benefits are horrible (like a 1.3% 401k match). If you’re not in the Boston Bros Boys Club, you don’t exist.

title: Run....
pros: Nice people, generally. Everyone bonds over how miserable they are and overall disfunction of team and leadership.
cons: Meager paycheck, ZERO culture, clueless management, extremely high turnover so nobody feels connected, no support/development or incentive to perform at highest potential, and lean teams are stretched way to thin so everyone is miserable and looking elsewhere

title: Senior
pros: Entrepreneurial; flexible; NY based HdQtrs; Focuses on driving a new strong culture; Cares about its most precious resources, employees...especially the revenue generators. The opportunities presented are great for the Originators from open geographies, to many lines of products and services available to fulfill their clients' needs, as well as great benefits.
cons: Old/past reputation still lingers in the marketplace, which is unfortunate because Arbor is a company that is renewing it's culture and engaging its employees.

title: Toxic Work Culture
pros: Banking Holidays, Laid Back and That's It
cons: Favoritism, Poor Management, No Real Growth

title: Sweatshop
pros: Good place to learn - thrown right into the fire, see a lot of deal flow - with exception of upper management people there are great
cons: No regard of personal life. Constant stress from upper management, originators, treasury, asset management, legal, just about every department. Empty promises from upper management, felt like was constantly understaffed and overworked. Late nights and weekends were common. Many people were fired, a lot of turnover

title: Fraternity
pros: 3% comp increase annually for most
cons: If you are not part of the inner circle, then it is very difficult to advance. Management expect miracles on getting work done. Technology is significantly behind as compared to peers. Lots of upper management hires but need people to do the actual work. Key executives have been there almost 30 years - no apparent succession planning. No employee stock purchase plan .

title: I thought I had seen bad management until I came here
pros: Only benefit is you only have to come to office when you feel like it, as nobody comes to the office. But God help you if you are new and need to be given any form of direction.
cons: Way too many to list so I will just list top cons... Absolutely horrendous management, no guidance, no leadership, no structure, no defined processes, and lying is standard form of communication.

title: Very fair place to work!

cons: Since Headquarters is based in Nassau, sometimes it's harder to get talent than if you were in NYC.

title: A Place to Grow and Learn
pros: The company encourages an entrepreneurial attitude. The people are smart, nice and hardworking. I love the creativity. Bina Handa is wicked smart and thoughtful in her leadership approach. cons: There’s nothing to note here.

title: Work, Work balance
pros: You will learn volumes and the pay is pretty good*
cons: *The pay is pretty good if you were to only work 40-50 hours a week*The teams are not put together well and they are severely understaffed. Some individuals doing the bare minimum, with no consequences. At the same time, others are expected to review work at home and remain on site longer than they already are. While this is a typical story, it is extreme here. The teams should be staffed with twice the personnel, possibly more. If you plan on leaving, make sure to burn up your PTO because they will NOT pay more than 40 hours of accrued time. (It’s buried in the handbook and legal)

title: Horrible job
pros: Good benefits and good pay
cons: This is a fine place to work if you only care about your job and do not want to have a life outside of work. The management could not care less about what you have going on in your personal life; to them, work should be the #1 priority in your life. You will stay late more times than you will get to leave on time (by far). You can try to leave on time, but you will likely get told that you actually need to stay until 9:00pm anyway. Working here was the worst experience of my life and driving out of the garage on my last day was one of the happiest moments of my life. I felt like a huge weight was lifted the day I left that place.

title: Avoid if you can, unless you like overwork
pros: Individual people were very nice, as long as you don't want to work as a team. Location is great - right in Town Center, close to restaurants and shopping.
cons: Silo mentality- there is no teamwork. Upper management has no idea what the lower level jobs entail, and thus assume that people have capacity to take on more tasks. They're always understaffed, and when they give you the workload of two people, there's no additional compensation.

title: Great place to work
pros: Armada Hoffler is a great company to work for. A very strong focus on safety, with additional safety training throughout the year. They only hire qualified subcontractors that have gone through a pretty rigorous qualification process. This leads to their projects running smoother than most and a professional work environment in the field. They are a mid to large company but they absolutely make you feel like family. They truly care about their employees. Wages are on par or a little above industry standards and their benefits package is excellent.
cons: I have no complaints about working for Armada Hoffler.

pros: None. Wait, the building is nice and in a nice area.

title: Things Could Have Been Better!
pros: They take a chance on those with no mortgage background. Everyone is very helpful when they can be. Some departments had the flexibility to work from home. It was typically very easy to take time off when you needed it.
cons: Hard to get promoted. There's a lack of transparency with what is going on with the company behind closed doors. it's hard to get promoted, especially if your are good in your roll. Can be extremely over-worked. HR isn't very helpful when it comes to employee concerns. There aren't any people of color in Executive Level Management, actually there wasn't but a couple of POC in management at all. There's no diversity & inclusion team, no team building - many of us worked in the office together but had no idea who one-another was as me only sat in one section over from one another.

title: Perpetually Toxic Environment
pros: Some employees (Mostly sales) gets bonuses.
cons: A perpetually toxic work environment with constant back stabbing and finger pointing between teams. Management is oblivious to this festering culture and in some areas contribute to its continuation. There is no upward mobility in the company. Most of the time you will just be moved into an equal paying job with no bonus structure and they will call it a promotion. CEO only cares about his sales reps. Every other member of the company could leave and be replaced (Which he has made happen before) and he would never notice anyone was missing.

title: This Company Laid-Off Staff w/No Notice - Employees were Blindsided
pros: The leadership provided lunch for employees on the last 2-business days of the month.
cons: Angel Oak Mortgage Solutions laid-off most of it's workforce in Atlanta on March 24, 2020, in the middle of the Coronavirus COVD-19 global pandemic, with no advanced notice given to employees. Employees were told that they would only be paid through that day, March 24, 2020. I was completely blind-sided by the insensitivity and lack of concern for employees and their families by the Angel Oak leadership team.

title: Very disorganized organization but good experience
pros: Got good experience in manual /Non QM underwriting (valued when going to other positions) Lunch paid for twice a month Was lucky I had a great manager
cons: Where to start lol - can be very stressful. Loans are complicated and can take hours to underwrite. I am lucky I an a naturally fast learner and can teach myself because they kind of throw you to the wolves and it is not the easiest learning how to manually do everything and with their system High stress enviornment - conditions could take as long as a new loan. You were constantly swamped when it was busy. Also if you had a bad underwriting assistant then you work could double. Luckily i had great ones The AEs are brutal and most of them are cutthroat. Wont accept a no for an answer and will go over you to get a yes. The annoying part is - sometimes management caved to them and you would be put in uncomfortable position of approving something you would not sign your name to Hours could be long and even when you take time off you could almost not enjoy it because leading up to it you had to make sure all your loans were mostly taken care of - otherwise people would moan and whine about it when you came back. Also when i said that i liked to leave work for hour lunch ppl laughed and said you’ll quickly leanr you cant here. They were right - after training - i never left the office for lunch during my entire time there. I had lunch at my desk because it was the only way to finish your work Benefits were not great compared to what you had to pay and pto was nothing special either

title: Toxic corporate work environment
pros: Free snacks and drinks every day when in office, lots of Brandywine branded swag, good health benefits, some great people to work with, huge budget for projects.
cons: The work environment at the company is characterized by a pervasive culture of competitiveness, where personal advancement often takes precedence over ethical conduct. Interactions with colleagues are marred by an ulterior motive to extract information that can be later used against individuals. Furthermore, the marketing department is overseen by managers lacking design expertise, leading to a lack of understanding regarding project complexities and time requirements for designers. Employees are unfortunately treated as expendable resources due to the abundance of job applications received. The marketing department witnesses a high turnover rate, except for upper management, who remain insulated from these changes. Attempts to address the excessive workload have been met with dismissive responses, fostering a tense atmosphere in the office. Interpersonal conflicts are rampant within the department, exacerbated by the exclusivity of decision-making among a select few individuals. Until the company acknowledges and acts upon the feedback provided, particularly concerning the need for a manager with a design background who can advocate for the designers, this cycle of high turnover is likely to persist. Unfortunately, the current project manager has not demonstrated the willingness or ability to fulfill this role. Additionally, the company does not prioritize the mental well-being of its employees, focusing primarily on meeting deadlines and discouraging expressions of concern. It is imperative for the company to reevaluate its management approach, fostering a supportive and inclusive environment that values the contributions and mental health of its workforce.

title: Your Mileage May Vary
pros: - Free pretzels and soft drinks - Great Center City location - Decent benefits - Good salary - Stable
cons: - Little interest in professionally developing employees - Lack of career and advancement opportunities - Lack of direct, meaningful communication from senior leadership, disconnect between perceived state of company and actual state of company - Treatment by and perceived value in company dependent on leadership's understanding of your department's role in company and department head's ability to play politics - Abysmal communication between regional offices and HQ, lack of accountability leads to repeated breakdowns - Corporate culture stiff to the point of toxicity

title: BDN review
pros: Great work-life balance; company has early closing on Fridays during the summer and also before most national holidays. This gives employees the opportunity to get a head-start to the holidays, especially if they need to travel.
cons: No clear path to advancing within company. Being a lean real estate company, with low employee turn-over, sometimes it feels as though there's no clear path to taking on leadership roles within company. You more or less have to wait till senior people move on, which does not happen often. If it does happen, it may be at a location that is not convenient.

title: Waspy and Plastic
pros: The office is beautiful and some departments are great.
cons: In accounting it is a toxic working environment. The workload is unreasonable and you are expected to work late everyday as well as on weekends and while on vacation or leave. Office politics are heavy and so workload is distributed unevenly and they suffer from being severely understaffed. As a result the turnover rate is incredibly high. When things go wrong there is no accountability from management and the blame is often unfairly shifted. There is also a 'firing culture' unlike anything I've ever seen. Anything bad that happens they sweep under the rug and because of the culture people are too afraid to speak up. It really is a nightmare workplace. Steer clear of accounting. There are so many other great places to work in Philadelphia, don't choose this one.

title: Toxic work culture
pros: - Beautiful office - Free coffee - Some people are genuinely nice - Interesting work + really cool projects underway
cons: - No company interest in personal development - Benefits are average at best (and no emphasis on work/life balance) - Toxic work culture in some departments - No respect of one’s personal life (taking PTO but still expected to be “on”) - Lack of true leadership in some departments - Not a “modern” company. As more companies place more emphasis on their employees, this one says they are but they’re not actually doing anything to improve the employee experience.

title: This is hands down the best company I have ever worked for.
pros: Here’s the updated review incorporating your new points: 5 Stars - The Best Employer I’ve Worked For Starting with CBL 9 months ago has been one of the best career decisions I’ve ever made. After 22 years in the industry and working with countless management companies (many of which left much to be desired), I was blown away by how different CBL truly is. Their vetting process was extensive and, though it was intense, you could tell they were on the right path and committed to finding the best fit for their team. From the very beginning, it was clear that they take the time to know their people and ensure they’re making the right decisions for both the company and the employee. From day one, CBL has exceeded my expectations. The interviews were engaging and professional, and it was apparent they do things the right way. Their commitment to excellence shines in every aspect of the organization, from onboarding to competitive pay and generous benefits. At the same time, CBL expects the same level of dedication and work ethic from its employees. But that’s easy to deliver when you work for a company that genuinely supports you, values your input, and stands behind your decisions. The work is challenging—this is not a company for slackers—but it’s rewarding. About a month ago, when the mall I worked at went on the market and was sold, I was initially devastated. Typically, when a mall changes ownership, the staff either transitions to the new owners or is left in a precarious position. After only 8 months in my role, I feared losing CBL as my employer. However, I reached out to HR to express my interest in staying with the company, and to my surprise and gratitude, they went above and beyond to retain me. Despite being new, they recognized my situation and offered to transfer me to a mall in another state. This level of care and support is something I’ve never experienced with a management company. The benefits CBL provides are incredible—almost entirely employer-paid, generous paid time off, and an exceptional work-life balance. The management team is phenomenal, with centuries of combined experience, and my boss is hands-down amazing. The pay is on the higher end of the spectrum, if not the highest, and everyone I’ve worked with LOVES this company. It’s no wonder employees stay for 20+ years. In fact, I’ve heard of many who left to try other companies, only to return months later because the grass is simply not greener on the other side. This review is completely unsolicited—I’m writing it because I feel compelled to share how great this company is. If you are top talent, this is a company you must work for. As long as you do your job, they will always show up with your check and have your back. CBL is, without a doubt, the best company I’ve worked for. I trust and value my coworkers implicitly—they’re not only great people but also immensely talented in their fields. I couldn’t ask for a better employer or a better team.
cons: None-- and I love to complain

title: Many good people, management at the top is exceptionally disconnected.
pros: There are some fabulous people that work at this company. If you're lucky to have a strong boss, you'll be shielded from much of the nonsense that goes on and actually be able to be productive and have individual growth.
cons: Corporate is clueless and quite disorganized. There are distinct cliques and "favorites" and a resistance to inclusion on many levels. I was actually at meetings where there was not a single female speaker featured and there was an exceptional celebration of sports coaches from Utah and of sports in general (I don't mind sports, but when that is ALL that is featured, it gets old). They will tout how important family is, however, they have no compunction about forcing work/travel on weekends without giving any comp time in exchange, which is just silly. I truly feel that the only reason one of the larger developers haven't done a take over of this company is that it would be too much work to sell the 50 ugly properties in order to secure the 15 solid ones and the 25 so-so ones. The IT department has a stranglehold and will actually actively discourage or tell VP level managers no to simple requests because they are quite convinced that they'll be hacked. And if you'd like to have a career path there - good luck. There is minimal opportunity for growth.

title: When it's good, it's all good, but when it's bad-look out!
pros: They are a very family oriented company. They have great relationships within the company. I feel like I have been compensated very generously.
cons: They focus too much on ROI! They need to extinguish the realtionship with ERMC that is slowly sucking the life out of our properties. Everyone rushes to make everything look pretty when we have a property review when in reality the property has their hands locked and not able to do what it takes to make the property look nice and run smoothly through out the year. Some regionals seldom visit properties and dont offer the help that we need. U feel like you are own your own! They promote people to higher positions that people in the field know of significant wrongs they have made yet go unnoticed. It's like if you click with them, your automatically in! There has been times, us in the field has sat begging for help and would get no emails, no nothing back-we would start working with each other because of no responses, yet this person got promoted?? I've seen too many times, regionals start with a project only for it to get dropped by the waist side!

pros: Well established retail REIT. Good people Decent place to get some fundamental experience.

Their heyday was in 70s-early 2000. The last 20 years has been denial of changing consumer and retail needs. Lack of opportunities. Many good and talented people left especially if not from Chattanooga. If local it’s one of very few public employers in town (the only Real Estate) Employees know that and so does company, so many stay because it’s the only thing around.

title: Dream job but nightmare manager. Was never truly part of the team.
pros: The salary was good, but I had to play a lot of hardballs to get what I got. Looking back, I should have asked for more.
cons: Management is a roll of the dice, and I got snake eyes. My manager constantly criticized me and never gave me anything productive to help me meet their expectations. Super stressful work environment and depending on your department you will be treated like an outsider. HQ is not a place for BIPOC unless you are older and prepared to do a bunch of brown-nosing. You must keep your head down, smile, and dance for your teams/ managers. I had a controlling manager that hindered me instead of helping with workflow. What I was promised in a manager and in my job description was not what the actual position entailed. The CEO walks around the office to check on employees constantly throughout the day and will comment if someone is out of the office or working remotely. When you are new, be prepared to have no work/life balance. And it still may not be enough to keep you there.

title: Arrogant Manager's Misogynistic Attitude: Creating Toxic Work Environment
pros: One of the things I appreciated most about working for this company is the level of flexibility it offers. As long as we deliver our work on time and to the required standards, we are trusted to manage our time and work at our own pace.
cons: The Manager's behavior has been consistently displaying attributes of an individual who holds misogynistic views. Their arrogance and condescending behavior towards women in the workplace are not only unprofessional but also deeply problematic. Moreover, their management style appears to be unsustainable as it creates a toxic work environment that can lead to high turnover rates and low employee morale.

title: Sad to see what it became
pros: I made long term friendships with the other techs and tenants. Vacation policy was good.
cons: COPT was a unique employer when I started and heavily focused on customer service and providing to the tenant. Multiple CEOs later and it became a shell of itself on past reputation and instead become a paper company focused on hitting metrics and accounting at the expense of the tenant. Highly political company. Do more with less became the norm. No clear vision on moving forward and morale was at its lowest when I finally moved on. No defined training plan for the maintenance folks or opportunity for growth left at the mercy of your chief tech. Major disconnect between HQ and the field. Management operated in sillos.

title: Run away from COPT!
pros: They do have excellent benefits, time off, and events.
cons: They are NOT family friendly. Although they give you plenty of time off, they question every single time you take off and give you a hard time. The mentality is very "corporate squared" and they love to micro-manage. Specifically the marketing department is a ROYAL MESS. They lack project management, organizational strategies, they have 0 knowledge of what it takes to develop material for the company and the management hierarchy is completely off. It is a nest of gossip! They will rip apart a coworker for the stupidest things. If I would have known how awkward and unorganized, I would have never worked for them! They've had two people in a row walk out on them... that means something! Do yourself a favor and keep scrolling past their job postings.

title: Used to be a great company
pros: The long time employees who are still there are good people. Flexible work arrangements.
cons: 3 CEO's in 6 years and numerous reorganizations have caused this company to lose its family feel. The customer, which used to be the number 1 priority, has been pushed behind the shareholders and stock price. Cost cutting and doing more with less is the new norm. Many of the "old guard" leadership has been purged and new management don't share original values.

title: Fantastic to work for
pros: Great work life balance! Clear paths for advancement, fantastic benefits, upper management is accessible and open to all employee opinions, criticism etc
cons: I don’t have many complaints. Working on property management means you have to be available to the tenant when they need it. However the company is very good at compensating time spent when that happens.

title: The constant fear and intimidation tactics used by them created a culture of mistrust
pros: The cleanliness and organization of the office contributed to a positive and productive atmosphere. The modern amenities and ergonomic furniture made it a pleasure to work in.
cons: This terrible company had a toxic work environment, where the well-being and job satisfaction of employees were not a priority for the CEO and management. The constant fear and intimidation tactics used by them created a culture of mistrust, and the constant lies, and deceit made it clear that they had no regard for their employees.

title: COPT
pros: COPT is truly a great company to work for. Professional and friendly atmosphere. Beautiful and clean working environment. The benefits are amazing and they are the best I've ever experienced. Flexible hours and ability to work remotely if needed. Quarterly Earning calls to keep you informed on the growth of the business and regular departmental meetings to keep you working together as a team and keep you engaged.
cons: There are no downsides to working with this company.

title: Most toxic culture I've ever beem a part of.
pros: If you get into the right department with the right bunch of people, then it's a great place to work.
cons: Without a doubt the most toxic culture I've ever been a part of Leadership is unhelpful, condescending and greedy. They promote people with big egos and presonality issues. Unless you are willing to play the games and pretend to buy into the BS you will quickly find you are boxed into a group or position with no chance of leaving. I feel bad for the kind and hard working people that are still there and suffering. Avoid this company at all costs.

title: Clerical Assistant
pros: Exceptional design and cleanliness to the Columbia office building. The CEO there at the time Mr. Griffin was very personable, smart and diligent.
cons: This was by far my worst job ever. I was offered a job as a low-level clerical assistant working with the two teams, the legal department and investments team. This was my first full time job straight out of college and I absolutely dreaded coming to work everyday. I would go weeks without seeing my manager for the investments team, so many worked and assisted the legal team. The assist I worked under was the executive assistant to the VP of Legal and she did nothing but all day but suck up to her boss while talking about her behind her back and boss me around. She treated me very awful, and would raise her voice to me over little things I did wrong to the point where I would go home crying every day. But, at the same time I felt bad for her because she would be treated twice as as worse by the VP, so most days I let it go. The remaining members of the legal team I worked under were extremely pretentious, rude and unprofessional. I left after only 6 months of being employed there and I decided to resign after I met with my two bosses VP of Legal and VP of Investments for my three month performance evaluation, which conveniently took place 5 months into my employment. At that time they decided to advise me that my performance was subpar and I was taking too much time off from work, mind you I had braces on at that time and needed to visit the Orthodontist pretty often. They explained I was negative and rude to my counterparts, and at that time they were probably right because I had had enough with my coworkers yelling at me and treating me that way. Needless to say I finally got out, six months too long. I’ve had several jobs since that one and no other job I’ve ever been in has ever come close to how bad this one was.

title: The daily struggles were real, and exhausting!

cons: If you're dreaming of an ideal job with workalike balance, know that this is NOT it! The daily struggles were real, exhausting, and EXTREMELY stressful! Working more than 12 hours a day doesn't seem enough for our manager and looks us as if we're lazy and lack dedication for our work! It's RIDICULOUS!

title: Poor Senior Leadership and Lack of Strategic Direction
pros: Worked with a high-performing, mission-driven recruiting team that consistently delivered results in a high-volume environment. Gained valuable experience leading national initiatives and building programs that had real impact. Strong peer collaboration and camaraderie among frontline recruiters.
cons: Senior leadership within Talent Acquisition lacks trust in their team and consistently fails to lead with strategy or vision. Decisions are reactive, not proactive, and often made without transparency or input from those closest to the work. There is a clear and persistent favoritism toward corporate recruiting teams, despite the high-volume team being responsible for filling the vast majority of roles across the company. Recognition, advancement, and compensation are not aligned with performance. Employees are expected to take on strategic initiatives or larger projects and scope of work with no end date in sight and without formal acknowledgment or pay equity. Concerns raised through appropriate channels were either ignored or met with vague responses, and in some cases, were followed by restructuring decisions that created unnecessary competition and instability. The recent return-to-office policy is rigid and outdated, with little regard for employee well-being or modern workforce expectations.

title: WORST COMPANY EVER
pros: Payed me agreed upon salary.
cons: Told me to prepare for 80 hour work weeks, if I took a break I wasn’t “committed enough” I worked 65 hours during the week and demanded I come in Saturdays as well. But get ready for the busy season. Disorganized chaos. Antiquated WMS. Unhappy workers making 18hr to drive MHE who are punished for not coming in days they never agreed to work. In truth this place is a Logistical nightmare. RUN FAST! IT WONT GET BETTER! Your concerns are relegated to well it looks like HR “dropped the ball” No other answers to the fact you were told your working 40 hours a week and now are expected to double that. Slave culture!

title: Order selector
pros: Different learning experience for sure. Decent pay for staying local.Acknowledging that this offers a different learning experience is important. It is a great chance to build a career and learn the ropes. These factors might make this opportunity an interesting choice.
cons: Seems that alot think negatively of the employer. And they expect alot to be accomplished in less then 5weeks it seems. If you don't from experience they'll terminate you.It appears that many individuals harbor negative perceptions of the employer. The expectations for productivity seem quite high. The timeframe for completing tasks is perceived as unreasonably short. This may be a significant source of stress. It is important for the employer to consider these concerns.

title: Great Place to Work

Competitive Benefits - Health insurance, retirement plans, and employee assistance programs are solid compared to industry standards. Innovation & Technology - Automated facilities and advanced systems make work more efficient and future-focused.

title: Close to home
pros: Work is very close to home and my supervisor is probably the best supervisor I’ve ever had. He is very flexible with my hours being i and a single father who has split custody so some days I have to come in late or i am unable to stay late when it’s busy. But he also knows that I will come in in the middle of the night of on the weekends to finish repairs so we have enough truck to get the freight where it needs it to go on time.
cons: Being it it a publicly traded company it is much more difficult to order and stock parts me need to do our jobs. Also tools for the shop that the employer would normally provide either never get purchased or a technician has to refuse to repair a machine/ truck until they have the proper tools for safety reasons. This is not at fault of our shop supervisor but more of the hoops that they would Have to Jump Through to get such purchases approved. Since americold purchased halls warehouses over 2 years ago we still have yet to receive a parts washer so we are forced to use far more brake clean than would be normally used. Not only a waste of money but a hit to employee health and safety. Also understaffing is a huge problem. I have a few friends who I would have apply but the income offers are laughable sometimes. I feel like if you pay good wages you will Get the people who want to work and take pride in it. And you can easily weed out the people who don’t want the money. But It just in our department that is understaffed but everywhere it seems. I have tried numerous times to get my child support payments taken out of payroll before direct deposit with no luck. Even been arrested and released due to this issue. But I also understand that the HR rep that I have has a lot of other people she is responsible for and things slip through the cracks. I do love working here and the people i directly work with but we were promised apt when americold took over like all brand new tools and lunches every month and much more and we haven’t seen any of it. And might I add when corporate reps came around after the acquisition of halls they talked a good game they said we brought each of u a gift… it was hats and water bottles. But they didn’t bring enough for everyone… that right there kinda set the tone. I did receive a raise when they took over which was nice but it was nowhere near what I was offer at other companies 2 years prior coming out of technical school. Like $7-$10 less.

pros: The pros that I take away from working at Americold is that you have alternating days off. For example, you have long weeks and short weeks. Long weeks you work 4 12-hour days and short weeks you work 3 12-hour days. You get 4 days off after your long week and you get 3 days off after your short week.

title: Run. Seriously, do not take a job from this employer
pros: Pay is good, with overtime and incentives.
cons: You'll be making that overtime all right. In theory, the deal with the union is that you need to be told before lunch whether you'll have to stay late for mandatory overtime. In practice, they'll tell you every day that they need you for twelve hours, then will "let you leave early" if they don't need you. Also in practice, expect ten to twelve hours a day every day, and mandatory work every weekend. There will be zero life/work balance: your life will be stacking boxes in a freezer.

title: A private equity company has big impact on Americold
pros: Americold has invested heavily in new systems during the last few years. The transition has been difficult and expensive. In the long run, Americold will have a well integrated and competitive operation. There are some good learning opportunities for many people along the way.
cons: A private equity company named Yucaipa calls the shots and Yucaipa is run by billionaire Ron Burkle. The strategy a few years ago was to invest, grow, and go public. The Versacold acquisition added a lot of debt and antiquated systems. The investment was made but the growth didn't follow, in part because of the economy. Going public turned out not to be an option. The management team that initiated and was executing the strategy has been fired or has quit and been replaced by a team that is charged with a strategy of cutting cost, leveraging the company with debt, and returning more profit to Yucaipa. This is why there have been layoffs the last couple of years and a difficult work environment for those that remain. Yucaipa certainly has a right to recoup their investment, but this will be difficult for the employees and customers to handle over the next few years.

title: Feuding management

cons: Communication is severely lacking. Vertically and horizontally. Underpaid for the amount of work, due to high turnover.

title: Terrible Management

cons: Managers favor each other for the most part. You’ll have a set schedule but yet they expect you to come in early & leave late. Terrible work/life balance.
