pros: None really, sorry. Unless your and executive with a contract that will pay you for years after they lay you off.
cons: Trust is their last name, but it is the last thing you will get as an employee and the last thing you should do as an employee. So the facts, in the last year people who have spent a career of 20 plus years building the company have been let go. Then they start out-sourcing everything from leasing, architecture, and recently even management. Only the Executives with their golden parachutes are the priority at this company, read the SEC documents and if interviewing ask how many people have been laid off / let go in the last few years due to a new strategy! Soon all that will be left are a few executives with sweet compensation packages and third party service providers. Look at the quarterly reports, after dropping dividend they are still paying out more than they take in, not a winning formula! No growth in stock, stuck with perdominatly older office space that is struggling and can't compete agains all the new buildings, and selling off of divisions. Yeah ask questions and tread lightly.

title: Positive & Energetic Work Environment w/ Endless Career Potential
pros: Washington REIT provides a fast paced work environment for motivated individuals who are passionate and excited about their work. I’ve found the leadership to be inspiring and I would consider the company to have a collaborative open door policy. As the oldest publicly traded REIT in the country, the firm had a reputation for taking on that persona - until recently. That being said, I firmly believe that both the new CEO and new COO have done an excellent job at reversing the firm’s reputation in the industry and delivering bottom line results to investors that are attributable to the firm’s strategic direction and growth.
cons: None – it remains to be seen.

title: Best career choice I've ever made
pros: I've been at WashREIT for nearly a year. Everything from the interview process to the culture, to the teamwork and community have been outstanding. Even in this short time, I have learned so much and gained such incredible value from working with this dedicated team. WashREIT actually lives its core values - you have a voice, you're encouraged to lead, and you are motivated to excel. I am very blessed to be part of such an outstanding organization.
cons: With the complexity of the industry, there are many applications and services to learn about when coming on board. I think expanding the onboarding experience to educate people about these various systems would be beneficial in the long term.

title: Outstanding leadership
pros: The folks on the executive team are very thoughtful about the vision they have for the company and how they implement it. Transparent environment / lots of integrity from leadership. They're focused on doing what's right for the people. No hierarchy or bureaucracy, just a place where everyone collaborates and feels valued, and all ideas are welcomed and respected. HR dept. is incredible and unlike any I've seen, at other companies you'd need to spend $$$ externally to get the same level of professional coaching. Another huge plus is that the IT department is top notch and they constantly strive to make everyone's job easier and faster.
cons: None that I've encountered so far.

title: How many folks over 50 years of age are you going to let go?
pros: None really. Got paid on time and had a fair amount of vacation Very old boy like.
cons: The last more than ten people let go have been over 50. Ceo is unapproachable. HR should be one director not two. Benefits good but health insurance ridiculously expensive. Stuffy atmosphere unlike when the former ceo was their. People scared about more layoffs.

title: Bad.
pros: For me none. Have been picked on and abuse...
cons: Race and orientation, Benefits have been good. Time off has been good. Policies need to be reviewed.

title: Great Company
pros: A leadership team that cares about their employees, opportunities for hands-on learning, inclusive and collaborative culture, dynamic community service that supports our local community, a company that supports environmental sustainability
cons: There are many opportunities to learn and grow, but at times you need to take the initiative to reach out and find them

title: Solid organization with hardworking, dedicated employees.
pros: Repectful environment, execs are accessible and fair minded. The company owns a diverse portfolio which is unique to peers. Company benefits are excellent, friendly environment, fast-paced.
cons: Since it's a public company, there is a fair amount of financial reporting required.

title: Bureaucratic, indecisive and redundant work environment.
pros: Great employees to work with, people are kind.
cons: Too much bureaucracy, paper pushing, and employee paranoia about job security within the company. Excessive and pointless reports required from all employees - too much redundant positions in the company.

title: Chief Engineer
pros: Good Pay, growing company, good peers to work around
cons: Top Heavy management, some facets of management are micro managed

title: Director
pros: Great organization, collaborative environment, great co-workers.
cons: Changes in company strategy was difficult for many long term team members.

title: A great company to work .
pros: -Great co-workers -Training opportunity -Great leadership -Opportunity for personal development
cons: not any that I can think of . Great Experience .

title: Culture
pros: WashREIT is an innovative and forward thinking company. Leadership is smart and they make themselves accessible to all employees
cons: The company lacks diversity within their line and senior staff levels.

title: Commercial Real Estate Management
pros: Good pay, benefits, location, work environment, holidays
cons: Reorganization caused several job loss

title: Worked for 4plus years
pros: Culture, great co workers, tenants are great, work is good, locations are in dc.
cons: Company downsized, management, vision, and culture changed.

title: A great company to work for
pros: Accessible Executives Good pay Good benefits Positive culture
cons: Residential buildings only, now. Sold off office portfolio.

title: Good for a short while
pros: Large Reit has properties centrally located
cons: No growth potential - expensive benefits

title: Nice company.
pros: team players job fun to work with .
cons: It's none a very good place.

title: Good Overall Experience
pros: Good salary and benefits, exposure to higher ups
cons: work load can get heavy at times, always transitioning

title: Assistant Property Manager
pros: Culture, vacation perks and flexibility.
cons: Could be a bit more transparency.

pros: Nice people are there so there’s that
cons: Not so. Ice people are there

title: Be Careful
pros: Engineers are friendly and reasonable.
cons: They treat their employees terribly. Micromanagement is prevalent. A lot of favoritism happening as well.

title: Great Place to Work
pros: I can't imagine a better management team.
cons: Long hours. Get ready to work.

title: Investment Analyst Intern
pros:
Friendly environment
Easy to talk to higher ups
cons: A lot of individual work

title: EPRT
pros: They buy us lunch twice a week.
cons: They don't like promoting from within.

title: Great Culture
pros: progressive culture that is ahead of the curve in the real estate industry
cons: competing priorities are at times difficult to manage

title: Smoke and Mirrors... be careful
pros: There weren't too many things I liked about the organization other than meeting some cool people. The bright minds tended to be younger and most often would leave eventually. The salary was competitive... but benefits were pretty meh.
cons: Probably the most bizarre place I've ever worked. The constant stress of project deadlines that were deemed urgent, micro-managers and directors, executives being extremely toxic and overall just a weird sense of everyone being on edge at all times. They say they care about employee well being, but in the end most of the people that stay for more than a few years are just 'yes' people who play the corporate game. Most of the bright young minds leave after a few years (rightfully so) I often had to bite my tongue in response to how my manager and director would speak to me when something wasn't working as expected. The WFH is a joke.. they say 6 days a month but that comes with caveats... no 2 days in a row, has to have manager approval, can't come before a holiday or after a weekend... it wasn't flexible at all. Additionally, every team is extremely under-staffed... the amount of project requests that would come in.. the team I worked within never had enough time to complete anything with real quality, as it was a mad rush to get it out the door. The firm was extremely wary of hiring more people, yet executive level salaries were insane... just food for thought. Unless you are unemployed or have no other job prospects, I'd carefully consider other opportunities. Obviously everyone's experience is different.. but in a nutshell this was the worst place I ever worked at (my perspective)

title: Good Entry Level Job
pros: Benefits are (were) the best I've experienced in the industry. Plus it's cool to say you work for the company that owns the "world's most famous building".
cons: So, I've had the privilege of working at a worse company and a company on par with (or a little better than) ESRT. If you're right out of college, looking for an entry level property management job to spend a couple of years at to get your resume going (because you will not get promoted, not matter how good you are. Rewarding good work or hiring from within is not their jam) you could do worse. The benefits are really good, actually. Although, they changed their bonus structure in order to deny or lower bonuses arbitrarily and they switched their insurance to a lower quality one right as I left, so I can't speak to how the benefits are now. Bottom line--you have to remember that this is a corporation in AMERICA, of all places. They don't care about you beyond if you're losing or making them money, no matter how many free bagel days or lunches they give you. At the end of the day, they will sell your building to make a buck and kick you to the curb with a backdated termination letter (so that they don't have to pay for your insurance, of course), a callous denial of severance (even though they gave all other buildings severance before you), and not even a thank you or goodbye meal (upper management didn't even email the people whose lives they were upending despite knowing them for 10+ years), whether you've worked there for 2 years or 20. In fact, you're probably treated better if you've only been there for 2 years because the CEO or whatever his nepo baby title is has some kind of obsession with Gen Z and doesn't respect lifers. And everyone is TERRIFIED of him so no one will fight on your behalf if they risk going against him. So, yeah. It's a fine place to work if you don't expect to get a lot out of it. You get good experience and meet good people but you'll most likely get stuck in your position with no hope of upward mobility.

title: Great Place to work
pros: Has been a great experience since the day I started. Team was always very welcoming and willing to help where needed.
cons: Nothing at this time to write on.

title: Toxic Manager
pros: Good Company benefits and salary
cons: bad management and no room for learning

title: Avoid
pros: You will never be fired.
cons: Idiots and sexist idiots. Kickbacks.

title: Great place to work
pros: Great place to work at
cons: Sometimes there's alot of projects to work on

title: Been a while since I’ve liked where I’ve worked
pros: Team is incredible to work with and they all work incredibly hard. Happy to wake up and come in daily.
cons: Very busy. Delays in process seem fairly common. They are working towards fixing from what I’ve seen

title: Toxic
pros: WFH once a week is a plus here.
cons: Toxic, no good managers lazy employees.

title: Love all aspects of working here
pros: Colleagues, meaningful work, engaging/positive culture
cons: Sometimes it can be fast paced

title: Don't Work Here
pros: A lot of great people. Progressive in a few areas.
cons: A bad experience. Many unhappy employees both past and present. Staff sees how some are treated and know it could be them some day. They really don't care about you and will use you until they are done with you. Don't be fooled by their facade.

title: Good company culture
pros:
Competitive salary
Good company culture
cons:
Very “corporate” structure system. 
Very busy

title: Not Great
pros: Good benefits and salary/compensation. Hybrid work schedule.
cons: Very strict. Micromanaged. Felt like there was a lack of trust between employees and managers. Some employees were hourly when they should be salary.

title: Great Company, Bad Management
pros: Great work benefits. Met a lot of excellent people here.
cons: IT Management was terrible. Constantly heard upper management screaming on the phone. Unreasonable deadlines for employees. Consistently expect you to work unpaid overtime or else face consequences. Saw multiple people quit while I was here.

title: Good
pros: Good good good good good
cons: Hours all over the place

title: A good place to work
pros: great culture, progressive environment, good pay, good growth opportunity
cons: work life balance, hours, flexibility

title: Smoke and Mirrors
pros: Salary was better than other companies
cons: Not a diverse workplace or psychologically safe workplace.

title: Employee Review
pros: Landmark building. Great for a resume.
cons: No boundaries, no work/life balance, time is not respected, hard work is not appreciated, lots of blaming/finger pointing, zero support. Some teams have a big turnover for these reasons. You may have events and work 14+ days in a row. They do not give any additional time off in return. They offer a work from home policy, but working from home is frowned upon and not allowed on all teams.

title: Great Team, Great Leadership, Great Company
pros: The top level executives here listen to the employees and their concerns. Since joining the company about 4 years ago, I have watched our culture continuously improve. We are getting better and better and headed for great things. The core team here has some of the best individuals I have met over the course of my entire career- kind, loyal, dedicated and hard-working. We genuinely care about one another and help each other succeed.
cons: The environment can be fast- paced and stressful but this is not particular to the company- this is the real estate industry in general. We have many policies and protocols in place which can sometimes bog us down but overtime, I have watched us streamline our processes and consistently look for ways to improve. This is merely part of being a relatively new company establishing its best practices. The pro here is that management constantly seeks feedback and we all have a voice in shaping these policies.

title: Onward and Upward and Right Off The Top of the Rock
pros: Beautiful Historical Building Awesome part of Manhattan to spend the pre and post work hours Close numerous happy hours that help forget the mickey mouse operation that is ESRT (If they even let you out on time)
cons: Working here is like riding a bicycle. Except the bicycle is on fire, and you're on fire, and you're in hell. If you should be so fortunate to prove your worth on the job, prepare for the higher ups to serve you a buffet of inefficiency, incompetence, and ineffective management skills. If you can handle that, management may further ask you to unhinge your jaw and swallow a heaping plateful of responsibilities that you will get 0 credit for (but 100% of the blame if failed) and an all day special of empty promises. If I knew what I was getting myself into, I would've just thrown my body into traffic knowing that NYPD and the DoT would be able to take care of my corpse better than ESRT with my career.

title: Not worth the space on my resume.
pros: Basically, it sounds great to colleagues and ex-coworkers when you mention you work at the Empire State Building. There are tons of great retail stores and places to eat in the area.
cons: They have unrealistic expectations of the work to be performed. Management sets double standards for certain employees. All the executives do what they want when they want and you may get two different conflicting orders from two different executives. Even as a salary based paid employee, we are required to be tracked using a fingerprint scanner. Some departments are no help and you are blamed for work not completing on time or incorrectly done. The benefits are the worst I have ever had the "pleasure" of using. Asking for time off, you may be talked down to as if you are a 2 year old child be scolded for not going to the potty. When you mention this to someone in HR that you thought would help, nothing happens. Management and HR seems to ignore the problem because to them the issue is always with the lower level employees. No wonder a lot of people come and go through my department.

title: The Worst of the Worst
pros: It's almost over and I am finally moving on after 7 long years...
cons: Everything! Senior Management is horrible. They treat employees like pawns in a chess game, play favorites, if you are not a part of the inner circle, good luck getting a fair and decent pay increase or bonus. Stock options are not give to all employees but rather only those deemed by senior management to be "worth the investment". When employees ask “who qualifies for stock options?”, no one can give a straight answer. The HR department is the most unprofessional I have experienced in my 10+ career in real-estate industry. Incompetent, incapable, and completely useless. The HR department experienced nearly 100% turnover since 2015. Everyone with talent in that department left. Pay increases, bonuses and payroll is horrendous and run by an incompetent manager. There is a huge lack of union and employee knowledge within the HR department. As for the Operations and Finance Departments, they will work you 90+ hours a week and it’s still never good enough. Increases and bonuses are laughable in comparison to the hours worked. This has to be the worst REIT to work for. If I could rate them negative stars I would.

title: ESRT
pros: - Annual bonus (probably will be done away with for a while due to COVID - Each employee gets a free pass to the Observatory - Nice office space - Some really great people
cons: - Toxic environment - CEO runs the place like a dictator - It's a old boys club so women are not treated fairly. - Preferential treatment across the board - ESRT does not value talent and they have lost some really good people because the CEO doesn't care about anyone - They also do not pay fairly. The reward upper management handsomely but those who really do the work are not paid their worth - Inflated leadership team - Employees are fearful of the CEO and his arbitrary moods - Located in a bad area of Herald SQ. Extremely congested normally and a large homeless population.

title: King Kong with an Ego to match
pros: Agree that the company's talent at the mid and entry level is a huge asset.
cons: Thought IPO would transform the company into new thought leadership and direction. Not so. Guiding principles are more dictatorship than motivational. Cliche phrases used by top management have the opposite effect. Stop hiring friends as consultants to "expose" what's wrong with the company, instead ask for anonymous internal feedback and then don't retaliate if its not positive. Fear instilled in every employee with Jekyll and Hyde tactics. No ethics to speak of, the difference between what is right and wrong does not exist. Good hard working new employees burn out quick and start to be brainwashed into puppets and nobody can speak their minds on business concepts or direction that defies the leadership.

title: It’s the Tower of Terror
pros: The union pay and benefits
cons: Cynical, tyrannical, malevolent. I used to like this job. But now...? Everyone is miserable. Top to bottom. You’ve got a New York City land lord who behaves like Stalin but thinks he’s Walt Disney. Maybe he realizes he spent WAY too much money on “improvements “ and needs a scapegoat. Hospitality? If you’re interested in a career in hospitality avoid the Empire State Building. It isn’t about hospitality. It’s a real estate company. This is an awful place. I’m doing everything I can to get out. Everyone I know there is looking for a different job. I’ve never seen anything like it. I wouldn’t let a friend work here. It is a truly unhealthy horrible environment to work in. They believe that a frightened and unhappy staff is more easily managed. Their contempt for the staff isnt even concealed. To them I’m just an overpaid Neanderthal. It’s a mean spirited place. Avoid.

title: Awesome Company
pros: In my own experience I have found ESRT to be an under standing and enjoyable place to work. Almost all the employees enjoy their jobs and it shows in the work that is produced. It's rare that you have to work long hours and when you do it is generally recognized. I would say this is definitely a company that you can achieve a healthy work life balance at without sacrificing your career.
cons: Occasionally there is a disconnect between what would be best for the company and employees and what the actual company policies are. More flexibility for employees (work from home, no time clock, etc.) would result in higher productivity.

title: Needs work
pros: Great coworkers and decent pay and bonus.
cons: Senior leadership is reactive rather than proactive and have created an echo chamber of negativity. Be prepared to hear about the things you do wrong and none of the things you do right. This is an oppressive work atmosphere with a top down management style. Senior leadership generally does not interact with front line teams and does not understand that this is a hospitality organization that needs to run on kindness. You need to reap what you sow.

title: Depends on what you're looking for.....
pros: If you prefer a monotonous repetitive work environment this is the place for you. However, there are some great hardworking people here in various departments who have a lot to offer.
cons: If you are looking for an innovative company with opportunity for advancement LOOK ELSEWHERE. The egos of micro managers stifle performance and overall employee happiness. There has been high turnover here especially during the IPO transition. The merging of management styles between portfolio properties created an imbalance in company culture, clash of egos, and an overall mess.

title: Focused and growing company with great people
pros: Great people, location, prestige and learning experience. There's been a lot of internal growth in all departments, especially this year. Excellent benefits and compensation package. High energy and very talented coworkers, and managers are genuinely interested in their employees' growth.
cons: The 401k match is low, somewhat big egos from senior leaders, no stock options for employees, no rollover vacation, NO FLEXIBILITY

title: Happy to be here
pros: I began my journey with ESRT during COVID-19. The company has done a remarkable job with my onboarding and engagement during an impossible time. I am appreciative of how welcoming colleagues were - even while I was meeting them virtually. The company is full of hard working individuals who are very passionate about their work. We have been on partial in-office and remote work and the company has gone above and beyond to make employees feel safe while back in the office. I am happy to be a part of this team and continue to learn more about the industry daily.
cons: I do not have any to currently share.

title: Image but no substance
pros: Great people work here....but not in high positions
cons: See below (you'll see what I mean)

title: Once right, Keep It Moving, Onward and Upward.
pros: If you want to hear "once right" and "onward and upward" 600 times a day while being verbally assaulted by senior management then look no further than ESRT. Generous severance packages depending on if you're liked or if the company is afraid you will sue when you leave.
cons: Zero growth, horrible management, verbal assaults by the CEO in front of peers. Females are under represented among senior management and are disrespected and mistreated. Requirements to succeed - Age 50+, Caucasian, willing to play puppet, and lack of common sense with a scent of entitlement.

title: IT Security Manager
pros: Company is on the move and seem to care about their employees. Great social activities and expect to have a good time with ESRT employees. If your looking to move along in a fast paced company this may be your calling. If you are lucky enough you might even have a chance to work with the great people in accounting, or with such leaders as Christopher Blackman, Ryan Klass, Keith Cody, Shanae Urisini, Rodney Gomes, or the amazing Tom Keltner. Tom, had to be one of the most amazing people I have ever worked with. You will work hard at ESRT, but your day will go fast.
cons: Retirement allocations / options / company match is below what most companies contribute today, or at least what ESRT competitors match. The ESRT Retirement program desperately needs a revamp which will help the avg paid employee. However, a bonus might make up the difference if (underline if) you happen to be in the right level position. So keep that in mind if you are not a manager/director. Use of personal credit card No Remote access / Work from home policy

title: Growth In the Right Direction
pros: I've been with ESRT for about a year now, serving in a variety of different capacities that have allowed me to witness multiple facets of what it's like to be an employee here. In my experience, there are two pros that stand out the most that have made it a great place to work for me: 1. A Challenging Environment - As mentioned in some of the other reviews here, when you put yourself out there at ESRT, you are rewarded with increasing professional and educational opportunities. I have found that management has consistently challenged me to go above and beyond and learn new things in my professional life. I've been given the opportunity to take great initiative on projects despite not being here for that long, simply because I've spoken up about wanting to be more involved. There are many opportunities for growth here at ESRT and professional improvement is actively encouraged by management. I have yet to be bored here. Obviously, this can vary by department, but I can say that I have been met with overwhelming support and encouragement from management in my department to grow professionally since I started here. 2. Increasingly Receptive Management - I have played witness to a good amount of institutional change here over the last year, all of which has ultimately been very encouraging to see as an employee. Management has been making an increasing effort to listen and respond to the concerns and desires of employees, which has manifested in a steadily growing number of "office perks" and the founding of a Culture Committee, as well as a general feeling of an overall culture shift within the organization as management learns to be a bit more relaxed and open to trying new things. Within the span of a year, I feel like management has gone from being very stuffy, close-minded, and out-of-touch to really being in touch with employees and actively engaged in finding new ways to improve the experience of working here at ESRT, which has been great to see and very reassuring. Aside from the aforementioned, I have also had a very positive experience with the work environment itself, and the people who work here. The job respects a work-life balance, the people are incredibly friendly and passionate about what they do, and the office itself is very upscale and conducive to collaboration and interaction among employees. I really do enjoy coming here every day!
cons: Despite its recent progress, the organization is still very reliant on a top-down style of management which has allowed a very bureaucratic environment to thrive. My main frustrations with working here stem from: 1. A Heavy Dependence on Email - My inbox is inundated around the clock thanks to a culture of reliance on email as a primary mode of communication. Slack is not a universally-used application in our office, nor do we use any other sort of IM service for communication. I think this is definitely something that could be improved on in order to reduce inbox clutter and increase efficiency. 2. Lengthy Approval Processes - As I said above, the bureaucracy of the organization is most apparent when trying to accomplish tasks that require several levels of approval. It is understandable to have procedures in place to reduce the company's liability, however there is a such thing as too much. It is not uncommon to spend a great amount of time on a project only for it to be stymied by lengthy approval processes.

title: Good Pay / Bad Vibes
pros: Great pay and benefits package
cons: Hosts are undervalued and treated as replaceable. There aren’t any options for progression. All supervisors are sourced out - meaning most don’t have the knowledge that a lot of the staff have. The building is frustrating and inefficient. There are no women in supervisor positions. There is a “boys club” atmosphere where men frequently talk about the attractiveness of the female guests and employees. They’ve used derogatory terms to refer to female guests and employees.

title: Senior level employee
pros: Excellent working environment, employees are motivated, senior level employees are very competent and provide excellent guidance to their subordinates. Company is very considerate of its employees' needs and is responsive. Very good company to work for.
cons: It may take a little time to get used to our our open office space (for those who have previously not worked in that type of office). However, the ease of interaction with colleagues and our modern office space including conference rooms far outweighs any period of acclimatization.

title: The worst company you’ll ever work for
pros: Great colleagues that are some of the best in the industry
cons: Insane top down management style. Does not treat employees like people and spends more time trying to punish employees rather than help them succeed in their positions. You can do hundreds of good things and be excellent at your job, but one slip up could cost you your job without any other considerations. A constant feeling of walking on eggshells, 11th hour decisions from upper management, and a serious lack of direction.

title: Great place to work
pros: Loved working at ESRT, it’s a great place to learn. Everyone is always willing and happy to teach/mentor if you’re willing to learn. Senior management has done a lot to improve the culture and seems to truly care about their employees through the implementation of various programs like flex work, flex fridays, enhanced benefits.. etc Had a great experience here and would recommend the company to all.
cons: Difficult to grow quickly must be willing to be patient

title: Sucks the life out of you
pros: It's really cool to work for the owners of the Empire State Building. Great networking opportunities. Great name for resume.
cons: Sucks the life out of you. Expected to work 'round the clock. Overworked and underpaid. Increased workload every year and have to beg for a decent raise. Low company morale. High turnover.

title: Good people but bad management!
pros: Really nice people! The people you work with are the best thing about being employed at ESRT.
cons: Management is not really flexible. Moving up is a rare thing at ESRT if you do you must be a favorite or a money maker but it takes everyone to make a company run not just a select few.

title: Onward and Upward
pros: Over the past few years, I've seen a shift in management for the better. They are implementing changes to display their appreciation for their employees. While no company is perfect, ESRT is aiming to provide a welcoming and more productive workplace. -Mgmt challenges you to become more well rounded and build upon your skills by taking courses and joining committees. -Newly implemented initiatives have brought up company morale: Casual Days, Gratitude Fridays, and Flex/Summer Fridays.
cons: -No work-from-home program -Lengthy Approval Processes

title: Great Place to Learn from the Best and Contribute!
pros: A forward-thinking, highly-successful company comprised of the industry's leading experts and foremost professionals. Passionate, caring and hard-working staff who strive for excellence. Collaborative, creative work environment.
cons: Requires high-level skill set and strong work ethic to succeed--which is not a negative if you are willing to work hard and contribute unique value.

title: Tyrannical Totalitarianism at its Best!
pros: Culture, what culture? If tyrannical totalitarianism is the culture you are striving for, this is the company to work for! The individuals working at the Empire State Building and its Observatory are some of the most talented professionals in the industry. Their other properties... not so much.
cons: HR, like most professions, values ethical principles. People are the most important asset of an organization but also its biggest potential liability. One would assume that HR is ethically responsible for promoting and fostering fairness and justice for all employees throughout the organization; however, ESRT’s disparate, discriminatory, and retaliatory practices make HR’s position within the organization obsolete. The greatest liabilities in the organization are the individuals in charge of running it. The top-heavy tyrannical executive office is compiled of “bosses” not “leaders” (all of whom hate each other and refuse to communicate with each other). As Human Capital professionals and culture champions, you know something is deeply wrong with an organization when 80% of the HR department leaves in 6 months to go work for the company’s biggest competitors. The executive office chalks employee resignations up to those resigning as being “bad employees”. If resignations were coming from “bad employees”, I doubt your competitors would be hiring them at double their salaries. When resigning, expect to get shunned from senior management. It is pointless to put in 2 weeks’ notice. During the notice period, not a single person on the senior management team acknowledges your existence. My advice to existing staff is – Get out while you still have what’s left of your morals and dignity. Competitors are looking for your talent and are willing to equitability compensate you for it. My advice to prospective employees is – Unless you’re taking a position making $300K+ a year, its best to keep it moving. Even at $300K a year, employees are dropping like flies.

title: Hypocritical management that creates a borderline toxic environment
pros: Environmentally
cons: cious, the OBS is cool, there are some decent projects if you're lucky

title: Happy To have left
pros: You will gain a lot of experience here as they throw many projects and assignments at their staff. You will also develop tough skin.
cons: Management places unrealistic expectations on staff with limited or no direction. They are constantly under staffed which leads to a tense work environment.

title: Tenant Services Coordinator

title: Stay

Some of the female supervisors need to be dressed more appropriate to the company standard no sneakers or Huggs boots (maybe on a snow day) and show the guests that they CARE because they are asking us but they are not doing it. UNDER-STAFF you have a 120 mins waiting time and you expect one host to do 3 hosts jobs in return your TRIP ADVISOR reviews will not be what you expected it to be but then again you surprised with the results and Blamed the Hosts when you should have hired or scheduled more people. One more thing is sometime you have a host spending the entire day there from early on until closing 2 AM after when scientifically proven after 12 hours the human brain is totally disconnected and is just on ROBOTIC MODE. Then you have the nerve to tell the hosts not to sound like a robot. The Employee are not set up to SUCCEED, they are set up to fail. January weather forecast 9 degrees windshield in minus you have a guard out in front with all face covered totally ridiculous. FAMILY MEMBER WORKING IN MANAGEMENT AND COVERING FOR EACH OTHER.

title: Meaningful Work That Makes a Difference
pros: Working at Howard Hughes is rewarding because the company is deeply committed to making a positive impact in the communities it develops. There’s a strong emphasis on thoughtful, sustainable growth and giving back through philanthropic efforts, which makes the work feel purposeful. It’s inspiring to be part of projects that don’t just build properties but create lasting value for residents and businesses. The company takes stewardship seriously, investing in green space, cultural initiatives, and community programs. If you want to be part of a team that prioritizes impact over just development, this is a great place to be.
cons: While the work itself is meaningful, there’s room for improvement when it comes to leadership and internal communication. At times, the company’s specific business objectives can feel unclear, and more transparency from leadership would help employees feel more aligned with long-term goals. Strengthening internal communications could also help reinforce the company culture, ensuring that employees across all teams feel connected and engaged in the bigger picture.

title: Great Company!

title: Terrible and disappointing experience
pros: Beautiful office space and free lunch.
cons: Executive level leadership over the team I worked on was oblivious, This particular leader of my team was demanding and flat out rude and had zero leadership skills. They talk about their BRICK values with R standing for RESPECT. Yet, this particular person only had respect for herself using foul language and bully tactics. Had a lot to say but not a clue on how to run a successful and thriving team. C-Suite doesn't seem to care and just enables the behavior. There is a deep dysfunction in the workplace. I am impressed at how well they do financially when the actual work environment l worked in was extremely toxic. Most people are unhappy. A lot of broken promises and you will be over worked and underpaid. Don't bother giving feedback because the powers that be think they know everything even though their department is a revolving door and continues to crumble. A LOT of gossiping in HR amongst one another - no confidentiality. The list goes on and on. Such a toxic and disappointing experience.

title: Toxic with High Turnover - Stay Away
pros: Attractive Galleria location. Frequent "Ordering-In" of dinner (explained below), and jean fridays.
cons: Extremely high turnover in the Accounting / Finance area (especially Corporate office). No work life balance. Unfortunately, accomplishment is measured on how many hours you put in (not the actual work performed). Dinner is ordered in just about every night and it's a big deal if you leave before 7pm (this is considered early). Employee morale is as low as I've witnessed at any organization of this size. Most people who are still hanging around are just waiting for their share grants to vest before they bolt. The joke of the place is that it's akin to Shawshank Prison (yes the movie). Existing employees actually joke when they see new hires join the team as they take bets on how many weeks the new person will last. **Last note - the financial systems are disjointed relics of the past. Running legacy software that is over 15 years old. It's really nothing short of a circus. If you are a candidate thinking of joining HHC, join at your own risk. My advice would be to make sure you ask them very detailed questions during the interview (and don't accept an offer until they let you interview with a couple peer level employees). Ask them pointed questions about the high rate of turnover (i.e.make them explain and defend it). Hope I can save some bright candidates from making a career move they'll soon regret.

title: It’s okay, it’s a good for a step to use to in your career
pros: Fast money, fast environment. Good for students to work at.
cons: No chance to grow, unequal work environment, micromanaging and bad management

title: Great Potential, Needs to Improve on Execution
pros: There are plenty of smart, talented people working for the company with a great pipeline of projects to work on. It is clear that the company is making strides to build a true company culture with the incredible effort put into Brand Marketing and People & Culture in the last two years. Shows that they are constantly looking to improve employee engagement with initiatives such as Hello Day and Discovery Tour.
cons: In many ways, the company is still being run like a start up. The lack of processes (or illogical ones with 15 hoops to jump through) has crippled execution. When you are new, or even have been there for several years, and ask what certain processes are, you just get shoved around to several different departments with no definitive answer. Senior leadership needs to step up and set these in place. There is also no unified platform for employees to effectively communicate or share files (not even Slack), something they keep saying they're working on. Depending on your boss and dept, there can be a serious lack of work life balance in New York office.

title: A- Culture and B+ Management and Business Process
pros: On one hand this company tries to embrace a forward thinking culture and for the most part they do. On the other hand, some of the executives are stuck in the past with old ways of thinking. The executive team in Dallas seems to be open to hearing your ideas. There are great benefits, some of the best I have seen. If you do you work, there is not much to complain about. There is a new monthly huddle for the whole office where everyone is updated on projects. Beer on Fridays is nice.
cons: Many of the issues that I have encountered are no different from every other company I have worked for. The office decor needs improvement and is cramped. Not very inspiring - specially for the corporate office of "most creatively driven real estate company".

title: Don't take the bait.
pros: Several very talented, dedicated people work here and those relationships are the biggest value. There is some creative freedom but that is mostly because of lack of direction from internal stakeholders. Good snacks, free drinks and all the other usual comforts but that is pretty standard these days.
cons: Totally chaotic with very little synergy between departments. Any ideas are the bare minimum of creative with a "throw it over the fence" mentality and ambition is heavily discouraged. It's been described as a "start-up environment" but that is just a way to dress up lack of strategy and low standards. Any attempt at departmental leadership comes off as clearly feigned and people are set up to fail constantly. Tonally it feels like you're working in finance and any perks of the office being pretty is clearly for clients, not employees. HHC tries in New York to be culturally relevant but often fails because there is very little creativity in its DNA. Across their other national locations (Dallas, Hawaii, Summerlin) HHC doesn't try to be something they're not and they do much better.

title: Learning Experience
pros: Working quickly Communicating with homebuyers Free Lunch
cons: No communication with employees Assumptions and judgments Locked employees in office everyday Mental Health declined greatly

title: Pier 17 at South Street Seaport
pros: Top of the line equipment and resources.
cons: Their expertise was not restaurants, so input from seniority was under-informed.

title: Good job
pros: Good starting pay and benefits
cons: PTO that that rarely gets approved

title: A company doing things right - understanding the "why" and innovatively executing their goals and dreams
pros: The culture of the company is just outstanding in that there IS one, and that this culture is one that says "hello". I joined BECAUSE of the promise of such a culture, and they certainly delivered. Everyone here cares deeply and passionately about the work that they do, the people that they work with, and it's amazing that they understand the importance of collaboration, innovation and having the know-how that it takes to succeed. The company focuses on its people - nurturing growth and empowering individuals to learn and do more.
cons: So far, the only downside I can speak of is that there are no current plans for a major master plan community development in Dallas yet! Other than that, Howard Hughes Corporation is a great place to work at and I look forward to learning and doing more myself.

title: Stay Away
pros: The salary. They will offer you a higher than average salary, but the hours worked are not worth it. You will be exposed to everything encompassing accounting to be able to put on your resume to help you get a new job. I’m not sure why we have other departments when it’s apparently Property Accountings responsibility.
cons: The hours. The amount of hours you will work will have your hourly rate close to or less than minimum wage. There is no work/life balance. Management says to bring concerns to them, but nothing will change for the good. The changes made only create more work and add stress. Constant changes that are not communicated. No one does everything the same. One person can be told to do it this way because that’s what they want, but it is not communicated to the group. Managers that don’t know what they’re doing. Everything falls on Property Accounting so be ready to take the blame. No one has answers for the proper way to complete tasks which leads to things being done incorrectly and management doesn’t seem to care. If you’re smart enough to be reading this then be smart enough to not even apply.

title: Great Place to Work!
pros: I've been at HHC for almost 2 years and the opportunities are endless. With our new leadership, the CEO and Chief People Officer have created an environment of inclusivity and the culture has shifted in a positive way under this new leadership and direction. My direct manager has always been open and receptive to my ideas and initiatives and welcomed me to spearhead projects and take ownership. I am empowered to speak my mind and voice my ideas to others in senior leadership. There is a part of accountability here that every employee should exercise, if you have an idea, or passion project, speak up, bring statistics/ facts, and leadership will give you the opportunity to execute. Do not wait to be called on!
cons: The organization is a little over 10 years old. In the past 10 years, the company has shifted to keep up with the real estate development market. Under the newest leadership the company is in a more stable place than ever.

title: Lip Service
pros: Space to learn and grow. Flexible with schedule. Friendly people and environment.
cons: Treated employees terribly when it mattered most. The Chairman and the two CEOs that were running the company while I was there spoke incessantly about how important the people of the company are. But when Covid hit, they used whatever means that were available to them to not take care of the people they laid off. The corporation likes to boast about how much cash it has on hand. It would've been nice to be paid a severance for the years of service we all gave to the company, especially during such a difficult time. Moving forward, they should stop telling their employees how important they are because it's a lie. There was also an issue with nepotism at the company.

title: A Great Company All Around
pros: The Howard Hughes Corporation has a small company feel but operates on a larger scale. The team leaders are open to your feedback and ideas. Its very fast paced and there is always something to do. Its a great place to flex your wings and really show what you are capable of and in turn get to learn from your coworkers. The majority of the people who work in my office are extremely hardworking but easy going and there is always something exciting going on around the office. The benefit package is amazing. We have tuition reimbursement, great discounts. Its definitely a great place to come to everyday.
cons: The company is growing exponentially and space is becoming an issue. It may be time for a new office.

title: Cheers to all my good memories!
pros: ros people culture employee cohesion and work ethic, company vision and direction.
cons: It's not what you know, it's who you know. For 4 years I thought I found my dream job and I was working for the best company ever . So I always went above and beyond and I always went the extra mile. Coworker became like family and I thought I will retired in this company. Until we got a new manager. From day one, the person had so much hate against me. Turning his face when he sees me . first time in my life I felt different and I saw how some people discriminate. And yes one wrong person can make you hate your job and just give up the relationship that you built for years with the company and all your dreams.well I moved on, one door closed and another opened.

title: Unprofessional and morally bad executives
pros: The only benefit to working here is the good name, which conceals how unprofessional this company is. But quickly, the industry is picking up on how bad Howard Hughes is in NYC, and it's getting a bad reputation.
cons: The executives at this company are running it into the ground. They are extremely young kids, with zero communication skills, zero knowledge, zero expertise, and zero teamwork skills. They just order all the lower people around, spinning them in circles with contradictory or not enough information. Then, when everything goes wrong (which it always does) they just blame the lower people. They have no clue how to run a company. The New York office is NOT profitable. The company just doesn't go under because OTHER cities make a profit and generate revenue. My boss is the worst person I've ever worked for in life.

title: Insane workloads, big egos and bad company culture. Do not recommend!
pros: A good place if you're looking for a fast-paced job and not a long-term career. Opportunities to get thrown into the fire and manage/learn a lot.
cons: Awful company culture, despite some failed internal effort to change it. Most employees here are openly miserable and desperately job searching. Egos galore!!! Major disconnect between cross-functioning teams. Insane workloads. Bad office vibes. All about who you know and not what you know. A lot of smoke and mirrors. Bad leadership. Terrible management, uninterested in helping their employees grow. ZERO process throughout the organization. No logic in the way things work, and no real openness to implement process. Insane deadlines. Bad work-life-balance. Old-school company with old mentalities-- Men often talk-over women in meetings, women struggle to gain respect or climbing the ladder. Employees don't respect each other or their leaders, a lot of drama and bad-talking. Unbelievable amount of turn-over!

title: Beware of Significant Uncertainty
pros: Decent work environment, pay/benefits and it’s a big publicly traded company
cons: Company has been exploring strategies to increase shareholder value, including a sale of company. Very high risk to take a job right now or stick around because the jobs could be gone very soon. Still, this “strategic review” likely was only done to get shareholders off the backs of management and to briefly pump the stock price. It’s been nearly 3 months since they announced the review and haven’t said a peep. After 3 months employees and shareholders deserve an update.

title: Depends on where you work/who you work for
pros: - A small and growing company so depending on your position and which office you work out of, there’s a lot of room for growth and autonomy - Really stepped up the benefits package in the past year - Smart and genuinely good people
cons: -The closer you are (personally) to top leadership, the better for you (in some cases to the point of nepotism). Makes it hard for emerging employees to make a difference -Top leadership is involved in everything so it can make small projects and processes drag on -Business and creative teams are often at odds which also slows things down -Can be superficial in some of their endeavors; a lot of talk and not much action - “unsexy” projects will get much less attention even if they are the moneymakers

title: Just meh.
pros: Compensation was good. They finally got stand-up desks and they go over the top on their town halls. There are a lot of initiatives they promote. They started a monthly stand-up for employees. It seems ok. A good way to get updates and ask questions of leadership.
cons: They don't have outside of the office get-togethers. Only "family" event is the holiday party in December, and that's where you have your +1. Leadership keeps trying to champion change, but it only seems to be marketed to new hires. No real action. They have their favorites employees, and everyone knows who they are. Leaders (Director level and above) talk badly about each other in front of lower-level employees.

title: Great place, worked there for 4 years!
pros: I started at the company right out of high school and stayed until covid hit. The woodlands resort as well as the Westin in the woodlands are wonderful Howard Hughes properties that offer great opportunity. The work place is very professional where you're treated as family. If you show dedication there's a lot of opportunity to move up as well. Management has always been lovely to work with and the benefits are really good too.
cons: The only con I felt was that upper management got switched up every couple of years and brought on significant change that was at times at the expense of certain parties and took some time to adapt to, but that's really anywhere. Can't think of any other cons!

pros: You receive discount on some amenities, but other than that small tidbit there isn't much to brag about.
cons: Toxic HR department as well as most of management. I gave my two weeks notice, showed up for the entire 14 days and did my work as usual and then I was marked as a no show for my last day. I didn't find out until the next summer when I applied to come back I was marked as unhireable. Not a fan of most of the management there, they don't really care about their employees.

title: Started Good, Ended Poorly
pros: Overall I would say I am grateful for the time and learning experiences I had at Howard Hughes. I was able to work on some pretty extensive projects and collaborate with people all across the company. I am grateful for my manager, they made working at HHC fun and always did their best to advocate for our team. Before the pandemic, I was able to travel quite a lot both for work and training. During my time there I also connected with a handful of pretty amazing people who genuinely wanted to make a difference in the world.
cons: When I first started at Howard Hughes I was over the moon excited. I was experiencing that "honeymoon phase" at a new job where everything is just amazing. However, that started to fade out as I soon realized that actions spoke louder than words. The main reason why I left was that I was looking for career growth. My current role was not providing me the room to expand my experience or push my skill set to the max. Another reason I left was I essentially lived in fear of losing my job for over a year and a half for many reasons and to no fault of my own. – In June 2019 the company wanted to be purchased which meant looming potential layoffs if we merged with another company. – When no one wanted to buy the company they did a round of layoffs just before Thanksgiving and another just before the Holidays. – In March 2020 mainly due to COVID-19 they did another round of layoffs. I was fortunate to survive 3 rounds of layoffs, but it was scary waking up every day not knowing if I was next. Lastly, the culture is not what it is promised to be. Politics and Cliques run deep on every level in almost every region, and not just with senior leadership. Anything embarrassing, goofy, or silly you say or do can and will be used against you even months after it happened.

title: Nice benefits, nice working environment, good people
pros: The benefits are really good and most of the individuals are knowledgeable and helpful. Lots of Corporate "bonding" events. Work/life balance is good. Pay is excellent.
cons: Lack of communication between departments. Lots of politics. Letting people go suddenly and not letting other employees know what is happening, i.e., restructuring of department, change in vision, lack of profits or general layoff. Sometimes uneasy feeling and fear of unknown.

title: "Leadership" that doesn't Lead.
pros: Young, dynamic, fast growing company with many benefits and perks...if you're lucky enough to have the time to enjoy them.
cons: The "vibe" of any company trickles down from the top. Insecure, narcissistic leadership cannot be the foundation for a happy and productive staff. They talk a good talk when it comes to recruiting and retention, but the proof is in the pudding: High turnover, Negative undertones throughout.

title: Toxic
pros: Lots of opportunity to learn; most people are a pleasure to work with; throws good parties
cons: Unhealthy culture; cronyism running rampant; executive management has entrepreneurial mindset - lacks clear direction/structure (Good for a start up but not a 5+ year old public company. Is this mindset hindering their ability to be more successful long-term in Corporate America? Time will tell.)

title: Mediocre, but with potential
pros: Great people, wonderful benefits, they have a really great appreciation of employees. They also spend freely on the latest business tools, education and training.
cons: There is a culture of passing the buck so that there is always one crisis after the other because nobody wants to be responsible for making a decision. Also, you would think with the Howard Hughes branding you would have Class A assets.... Like I said, mediocre at best.

title: Fast Pace : Awesome Place
pros: Many opportunities to succeed. Training is available if you want it. Benefits are incredible.
cons: Very demanding environment and lots of stress Directions can be vague and hard to understand the goals. You are responsible for many activities which can stretch you pretty thin.

title: Fun Perks, Bad Work Enviornment
pros: -Fun work events and out of office opportunities -Free snacks and beautiful office views -Certain amount of creative freedom
cons: Toxic work environment. Most employees are openly miserable, place blame and are rude to one another. Terrible management structure with little to no support or project management. The company has gone through mass layoffs leaving employees with a constant fear of losing their jobs.

title: Sr. Desktop & System Engineer
pros: Fair wages and decent benefits, and a few friendly people.
cons: The company is still young and growing, so there is some turnover as they try to get there footing. The different groups (creative vs executive) in the NY location and the management in Dallas are at times at odds and it can lead to pressure situations that are unnecessary with better communication.

title: This job has been a big disappointment.
pros: I love the location in the waterway in the Woodlands. I enjoy most of my co-workers and my immediate supervisors are cool.
cons: Upper management is a joke and don't know how to run an upscale hotel. They don't value employees. Many have quit and things still don't change. Money is very bad.

title: Great Company / No Employee Loyalty
pros: Howard Hughes is overall a great company. They are growing rapidly and the CEO is a very smart man.
cons: There is no loyalty to employees that have been with the company for several years. Rather than promote from within, they'd rather lay off and change the title to hire someone new.

title: Personal thoughts
pros: Employees are treated with respect, based on my observations they are considered to be a very important asset. Senior Management is approachable. There are lots of opportunities to learn and grow within the organization.
cons: There is too much food... So hard to stay true to a diet.. :)..

title: Great Benefits but....
pros: Benefits offered by the company are great
cons: Absolutely no flexibility for remote work options

title: Management lacking "leadership" skills.
pros: A few great coworkers, some decent perks, not too much overtime.
cons: Leadership simply waiting for retirement, thus no interest in developing staff into future leaders. Minimal communication between staff and management.

title: Rewards Performance
pros: HHC provides upward mobility to people who perform. Regardless of experience level or qualifications if you perform well there's potential for career advancement. If you are able to get in and show your value you will be rewarded.
cons: The work environment can be demanding. Be prepared to be "on" most all the time with an expectation to be available at home or on vacation. This ebbs and flows based on projects and work flow, but if having uninterrupted time is important you be wary.

title: Accounting
pros: Hard working group that works hard to get the job done. Intuitive and always looking for new ways to get things done.
cons: Top executives have no concern for the hard working employees that keep the company running. Lots of egos from all levels. Management does not manage titles appropriate to skill level.

title: Figuring out what it wants to be
pros: A sustainable model for long-term revenue with its MPC's. Strives for employee satisfaction. Secure financial standing and not over leveraged.
cons: Struggles to inspire employees with the work outside of the visions of grandeur regarding South Street Seaport which the majority of the employees of the company will never get to see.

title: Actions speak louder than words
pros: The company has some lofty ideals about what it could one day be - if only it tried to embody those words. Compensation and benefits are on par for the industry. The New York office has a beautiful view.
cons: We can learn a lot about a company from the way it has handled the COVID-19 crisis. HHC chose to let go of most of its employees, and then send them an email bragging about a "generous donation" made to a charity that "is prepared to provide financial assistance with rent, mortgage, utility and food" while acknowledging that this charity provides no individual grants and this donation is functionally useless to the jobless employees fearful for their families' futures. To add insult to injury, attached to the email was instructions on how to apply for food stamps. This is typical of operations of this company. The white, male leadership makes unilateral, ill-advised decisions without regard for the advice of those hired to help them steer the company in the right direction. Middle management acts as a barrier between the employees and leadership. Communication is a failure at every level: meetings are held to distribute old, contradictory, or useless information, while useful information is kept secret and employees are challenged to prove why they need critical details to do their jobs. Meanwhile, the nepotistic patriarchy is kept alive and well by creating special positions for the sons of white leadership. Well-designed lip service is paid to social causes on social media (when the lawyers and financial projections have determined it’s safe) but take a look at the leadership – that will speak louder than any pretty, convenient words. If you end up on an interview here, don’t let them read their values off a poster. Ask them how they demonstrate those values. For me, they couldn’t.

title: Good Opportunity yet occasional challenges
pros: Intelligent hard working teams. There's a ton of opportunity if you can focus on your goals and get linked up with the right people.
cons: Slightly disorganized, mildly chaotic. Lack of communication among the masses is the biggest fault. High turnover rate at times, disgruntled staff depending on the team.

title: Acounting
pros: Great Benefits and leadership. The people at the company make this one of the best places I have ever worked. I enjoy coming in everyday. The company prides themselves with a culture that is beyond anything I have seen at other places.
cons: The only con is in the accounting department is Quarter close is a beast and makes for a rough week for close.

title: Great Opportunities
pros: I've been working at HHC for a few years and have found it to always be a place where hard work is rewarded and opportunities plentiful. If you're entrepreneurial and driven you'll appreciate working here. Recent leadership changes have bolstered this mindset and there are many exciting projects in the pipeline.
cons: Nothing aside from the usual gripes of any corporate environment - too many meetings!

title: Much change going on, new management direction
pros: High end real estate and development work, good funding, great set of assets, energetic employees
cons: Major change of business plans from year to year, focus on growth. Recent upper executive changes fractured company, sold off some assets, moved headquarters from Dallas to Houston.

title: Medical BEnefits
pros: there are absolutely no pros
cons: Howard Hughes has sunk to a new low. They have made separating with the company due to COVID the most horrible experience at a time when people are at their most vulnerable. After not providing severance to hundreds of people, they have now , in the last week of December, terminated COBRA medical benefits. THE LAST WEEK OF DECEMBER AND THEY CUT PEOPLE AND THEIR FAMILY's MEDICAL BENEFITS.

title: Entrepreneurial Vibe with Organized Chaos
pros: Seasoned professionals (+25 years experience), young company with awesome spirit, innovative and creative, passion for excellence, invest in their people, opportunity for growth.
cons: Young company that has its issues, data validation, lots of senior people, long hours, political.

title: Great Culture
pros: The Howard Hughes Corp. has a great culture and really tries to nurture it's employees goals and interests. Everything moves at a very fast pace, so you have to willing to jump in when necessary and work as a team to get the job done. I believe you're rewarded well for your hard work.
cons: No cons to mention at this time

title: A culture that cares backed by incredible people and projects
pros: Leadership provides lots of room for creativity and growth; travel opportunities; loyalty among colleagues; genuinely interesting and engaging work because of the revolutionary properties and developments
cons: Immediate attention to multiple tasks is often needed, but it provides for a fast-paced environment; work hours can tend to be late, but many members of teams stay - not just one person

title: Would not reccomend
pros: They offer some easy summer jobs
cons: Terrible management, multiple waves of firing and hiring after every quarterly earnings statement. They would rather buy a 100,000 Mercedes sprinter van that they didn’t even use than keep on a tenured employee with 15 years with the company (not me). No job security at all.

pros: The Howard Hughes Corporation was one of the best environments that I have ever worked in. Everyone at the company is friendly, driven, and an overall joy to work with. I was part of the first full internship program with 15 other college interns and had one of the best summers ever. Great company.
cons: I had no problems with working here.

title: Great Place to work but...
pros: Amazing Culture! Great People
cons: Poor or non-existent training. Frustrating glacial pace of the contract approval process. Tedious and Ineffective internal controls and processes which cripple productivity and delivery of projects. Reactive rather than Proactive environment. High turnover of great talent due to frustrating illogical processes.

title: Amazing Company
pros: Excellent company with dynamic leadership. Highly entrepreneurial culture that challenges all employees to continually push through plateaus. Great portfolio of assets - working on large, meaningful projects. Hard work is rewarded.
cons: Depending upon personality type - not a good environment for those that prefer significant structure and predictability in their work/schedule.

title: Empty
pros: conveniently located in a beautiful area
cons: Corporate cultural push for the 24/7 work commitment. Lack of internal opportunties. Lack of communication and direction at all levels...very much a figure out as you go environment.

title: Poor Middle Management
pros: Decent paying job in Hawaii - not many of those.
cons: Highly tiered org. Current lower level employees have to deal with poor middle management at the sales, marketing, and PR. HR is more or less useless and works for middle management. The whistleblower line is a political play.

title: HOW TO ENGAGE EMPLOYEES IN 2019
pros: No one company in my many years in the industry can engage and inspire people like our team at The Howard Hughes Corporation. From the new employee orientation, aka "HELLO" to ongoing interactions with corporate peeps....are truly an inspirational experience.
cons: none to mention...all very positive thoughts!

title: Incredible Opportunities
pros: Howard Hughes truly rewards employees for work well done and provides several opportunities for growth and learning to those who take initiative. Leadership is very accessible.
cons: Sometimes there is lack of communication and clarity on overall company vision/strategy from corporate management.

title: Finding its Footing
pros: HHC is a new company so it naturally has some hiccups to work through. However, these hiccups are tackled head-on and solved in a sustainable manner that sets teams up for success.
cons: Processes can be slow and some properties have yet to adjust to new approaches.

title: Overall good, but leadership could be improved!
pros: Benefits are great. Bonuses every year.
cons: Local leadership could be better. Certain people getting promoted versus others who do not when they appear to be working just as hard or for longer period of time.

title: Disappointed.
pros: Upscale, good clientele. Coworkers are nice, and just as disgruntled as I am. Good benefits and provided outfits. Always smells good.
cons: Demanding, unfair, upper management. Payment is screwy. They have no faith in lower level management, and is too corporate to get anything done quickly.

title: Good Family Atmosphere, but NO Work/Life Balance
pros: some shwag... gifts, tshirts, bags, parties. great colleagues (with exceptions)
cons: "working hard is fun!"... kill yourself and sacrifice for a company who will not be loyal in return. politics and favoritism

title: 4 stars
pros: great company with big financial backing
cons: large company and somewhat bureaucratic

title: Premier real estate and development company
pros: Financially secure and great business plan. Well respected. Development assets are outstanding.
cons: Chasing too many rabbits without focus. Always going for the next best thing. People management suffers and talented employees move on.

title: Management needs to be looked at
pros: My coworkers were the best and I enjoyed working with them so much
cons: The middle management is not great here. I think HR or the org needs to take a closer look at what is causing attrition particularly in the marketing team. All fingers point to middle management. Some people shouldn’t be managing people and this is one of those cases here.

title: Know What You Want
pros: Willing to pay, decent room to grow
cons: Uncertain management direction, in total. Definite lack of restaurant experience at the decision-making level.

title: Great company to work for
pros: Work life balance, the benefits are amazing and upper management really cares about their employees.
cons: I really Have no complaints

title: Great place to start your career
pros: Tremendous amount of pipeline across all regions provides great opportunities to lead projects through to execution
cons: It’s MPC model creates for a very insular somewhat utopian way of development - staggers entrepreneurship development opportunities

title: Interesting crossover between Hospitality and Real Estate

cons: Appreciation is hardly given when it's deserved. You'll get walked all over if you don't pay attention.

title: You've never worked for a team like this one.
pros: Team oriented, no really, they all work together. Good honest people, hard working.
cons: Real Estate is a cyclical business, so there are ups, and there are downs.

title: Terrible Leadership
pros: Nice view and ESPN is in the same building
cons: Their leadership is corrupt and incompetent from the very top. They should stick to what they know. Hospitality is not their thing

cons: I do not have any

title: Howard Hughes Corp

title: This Company is Not What it Used to Be
pros: Although there are some great people working here, others not so much and these are in the leadership/c-suite area. Overall benefit package is good with matching 401-K; $.75 per dollar on your first 6% invested. FSA on heath/child care/elder care. HSA and traditional health, dental, and vision programs. ESPP at discount, LTD and STD. Catastrophic health plans as well. The elephant in the room is that salary lags behind, especially if you've been there for some time. New hires will come in at higher salary amounts. Field personnel will receive an iPhone that can be used personally, and some receive laptops. Three weeks of vacation plus two personal holidays in addition to traditional holidays. Sick time is liberal right now.
cons: Several years ago there was a fantastic CEO who was a servant leader. He knew everyone in the company, and worked his way up from just cutting the grass. Unfortunately now there is a different CEO who is more ego-centric. He has never held a position in operations having come out of the financial sector. The others in the c-suite are a mixed lot with some attempting to communicate with those outside of the c-suite while others are focused on their own country club life. This company has fully embraced DEI and ESG to the point of ignoring just why they are even in business. Navigating around this is like picking your way through a minefield! Too many of the great, seasoned employees have left due to the low pay, c-suite attitude, DEI and ESG b.s. and poor leadership in some of the divisions. One division had approximately 10 vacancies at the same time. Of course this affects the morale of others as they are forced to pick up the slack. The hiring process can be lengthy. Advancement can be non-existent depending on what position you hold.

title: Experience at Highwoods
pros: - additional work phone - work laptop - vendors take management out to lunch often - various class A buildings, you could possibly work at - prestigious name and reputable company
cons: - work/life balance may come array as you move up the leadership change - leadership has a hard time wanting to pivot, and get adjusted to new times within employee culture and work/life balance culture. - no incentives like our competitors to retain employees

title: Great Company!

cons: Pay scale, inter office politics

title: Great culture and work life balance

pros: Great benefits, friendly colleagues, nice amenities

title: Awesome Family
